revision.text:
{{Year nav topic5|1714|literature}}
This article presents lists of the literary events and publications in '''1714'''.
==Events== * March – The [[Scriblerus Club]], an informal group of literary friends, is formed by [[Jonathan Swift]], [[Alexander Pope]], [[John Gay]], [[John Arbuthnot]] (at whose [[London]] house they meet), [[Thomas Parnell]], [[Henry St John, 1st Viscount Bolingbroke|Henry St. John]] and [[Robert Harley, 1st Earl of Oxford and Mortimer|Robert Harley]].<ref>{{cite web|first=Valerie|last=Rumbold|title=Scriblerus Club (act. 1714)|work=[[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]]|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2009|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/theme/71160|accessdate=2011-02-04}} {{ODNBsub}}</ref> *[[July 4]] – Death of scholar [[Antonio Magliabechi]]; he bequeaths his personal library to his patron [[Cosimo III de' Medici, Grand Duke of Tuscany]], to serve as a [[public library]] for the city of [[Florence]], foundation of the [[National Central Library (Florence)|National Central Library]]. *[[July 27]] – [[Robert Harley, 1st Earl of Oxford and Earl Mortimer|Robert Harley]] is dismissed as [[Lord High Treasurer]] of Great Britain.<ref name="Cassell's Chronology">{{cite book|last=Williams|first=Hywel|title=Cassell's Chronology of World History|location=London|publisher=Weidenfeld & Nicolson|year=2005|isbn=0-304-35730-8|page=294}}</ref> *[[August 1]] – George, elector of [[Hanover]], becomes King [[George I of Great Britain]] following the death of [[Anne, Queen of Great Britain|Queen Anne]].<ref name="Cassell's Chronology"/> This places many writers in opposition to the new [[Whig (British political party)|Whig]] ministry and brings about the rise of [[Robert Walpole]] and indictment of [[Henry St John, 1st Viscount Bolingbroke|Henry St. John]]. * [[Samuel Garth]], poet and royal physician, is knighted by King [[George I of Great Britain]]. * [[Esther Vanhomrigh]] pursues [[Jonathan Swift]] to Ireland. * [[Moses ben Avraham Avinu]] is imprisoned in [[Halle (Saale)|Halle]] for printing [[Hebrew]] texts with supposedly anti-Christian content, but escapes to [[Amsterdam]]
==New books== <!-- (''Title of published book translation''), ("Title of published poem/story translation"), (Literal translation of title) --> ===Prose=== *Anonymous **''A Compleat Key to The Dispensary'' (response to [[Samuel Garth]]'s [[1699 in literature|1699]] poem) **''The Court of Atalantis'' (attributed to [[Delarivier Manley]] or possibly [[John Oldmixon]] or others) **''The Ladies Tale'' (stories) **''The Ladies Library'' (ed. [[Richard Steele]]) *[[John Arbuthnot]] **''A Continuation of the History of the Crown-Inn'' **''A Postscript to [[John Bull]]'' *[[Anne Dacier]] – ''Des Causes de la corruption du goût'' (On the Causes of the Corruption of Taste, in defence of Homer) *[[Daniel Defoe]] – ''A Secret History of the White-Staff'' (reporting allegations against Harley) *[[William Diaper]] – ''An Imitation of the Seventeenth Epistle of the First Book of Horace'' *[[Thomas Ellwood]] – ''The History of the Life of Thomas Ellwood'' *[[Laurence Eusden]] – ''A Letter to Mr Addison, on the King's Accession to the Throne'' *[[John Fortescue (judge)|Sir John Fortescue]] – ''The Difference between an Absolute and a Limited Monarchy'' (written c. 1473) *[[Charles Gildon]] – ''A New Rehearsal'' (an attack on Pope, ''et al.'') *[[Anthony Hamilton (writer)|Anthony Hamilton]] – ''Memoirs of the Life of the Count de Grammont'' (translation of [[Abel Boyer]]) *[[William King (poet)|William King]] et al. – ''The Persian and the Turkish Tales, Compleat'' *[[Gottfried Leibniz]] – ''[[La Monadologie]]'' *[[John Locke]] – ''The Works of John Locke'' (posthumous) *[[Bernard de Mandeville]] – ''[[The Fable of the Bees]]'' *[[Delarivier Manley]] – ''The Adventures of Rivella; or, The History of the Author of the Atalantis'' (quasi-autobiography) *"Captain" Alexander Smith – ''The History of the Lives of the Most Noted Highway-men, Foot-pads, House-breakers, Shop-lifts, and Cheats...'' *[[Richard Steele]] **''The Crisis'' **''The Englishman'' (collection and end of the periodical) **''The Lover'' (periodical) **''Mr Steele's Apology for Himself and his Writings'' **''The Public Spirit of the Tories'' (attrib.: response to Swift) **''The Reader'' (periodical) *[[Jonathan Swift]] – ''The Public Spirit of the Whigs'' *[[Ned Ward]] – ''The Field-Spy'' *[[Edward Young]] – ''The Force of Religion''
===Drama=== *[[William Shakespeare]] – ''The Works of Mr William Shakespear'' (ed. [[Nicholas Rowe (writer)|Nicholas Rowe]], 3rd edition) *[[Susanna Centlivre]] – ''The Wonder! A Woman Keeps a Secret'' *[[General Robert Hunter|Robert Hunter]] – ''[[Androboros]]'' *[[Charles Johnson (writer)|Charles Johnson]] – ''The Victim'' *[[Nicholas Rowe (dramatist)|Nicholas Rowe]] – ''The Tragedy of [[Jane Shore]]''
===Poetry=== *[[Abel Evans]] – ''Prae-existence: A poem, in imitation of Milton'' *[[John Gay]] – ''The Shepherd's Week'' *[[Alexander Pope]] – ''[[The Rape of the Lock]]'' *[[Nicholas Rowe (writer)|Nicholas Rowe]] – ''Poems on Several Occasions'' *[[Richard Steele]] – ''Poetical Miscellanies'' (with contributions from Pope, [[Thomas Parnell]], [[John Gay]], [[Thomas Warton]], [[Edward Young]], etc.) *[[Jonathan Swift]] – ''The First Ode of the Second Book of Horace Paraphras'd''
==Births== *[[January 1]] – [[Kristijonas Donelaitis]], Prussian Lithuanian poet (died [[1780 in literature|1780]]) *[[February 26]] – [[James Hervey]], English writer (died [[1758 in literature|1758]]) *[[April 14]] – [[Adam Gib]], Scottish theologian (died [[1788 in literature|1788]]) *[[May 6]] – [[James Townley]], English dramatist (died [[1778 in literature|1778]]) *[[November 13]] – [[William Shenstone]], English poet (died [[1763 in literature|1763]]) *[[December 16]] (December 27 [[New Style]]) – [[George Whitefield]], English preacher in American colonies (died [[1770 in literature|1770]]) *December – [[Jane Collier]], English novelist (died [[1755 in literature|1755]]) *''Unknown dates'' **[[Anica Bošković]], [[Republic of Ragusa|Ragusa]]n writer (died [[1804 in literature|1804]]) **[[James Parker (publisher)|James Parker]], American printer and publisher (died [[1770 in literature|1770]]) **[[Marie Jeanne Riccoboni]], French actress and dramatist (died [[1792 in literature|1792]])
==Deaths== [[File:Choganji (Tennoji, Osaka) Takemoto Gidayu haka.jpg|200px|thumb|Tomb of Takemoto Gidayū in Osaka]] *[[January 17]] – [[Gabriel Álvarez de Toledo]], Spanish royal librarian and poet (born [[1662 in literature|1662]]) *[[March 3]] – [[Hans Carl von Carlowitz]], German administrator and writer on forestry (born [[1645 in literature|1645]]) *[[June 22]] – [[Matthew Henry]], Welsh Biblical commentator (born [[1662 in literature|1662]]) *[[June 28]] – [[Daniel Papebroch]], Flemish Jesuit hagiographer (born [[1628 in literature|1628]]) *[[July 4]] – [[Antonio Magliabechi]], Italian scholar and librarian (born [[1633 in literature|1633]]) *[[October 18]] – [[Takemoto Gidayū]] (竹本 義太夫), Japanese ''[[jōruri (music)|jōruri]]'' chanter and playwright (born [[1651 in literature|1651]])<ref>{{cite book|last=Gerstle|first=Drew|title=Chikamatsu: Five Late Plays|location=New York|publisher=Columbia University Press|year=2001|pages=10–18}}</ref> *[[November 7]] – [[Charles Davenant]], English economist (born [[1656 in literature|1656]]) *[[December 15]] – [[Silvester Jenks]], English Catholic theologian and philosopher (born [[1656 in literature|1656]])
==In literature== *[[July 20]] – The fictional event narrated in [[Thornton Wilder]]'s novel ''[[The Bridge of San Luis Rey]]'' ([[1927 in literature|1927]]) takes place.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{authoritycontrol}} [[Category:1714 books| ]] [[Category:Years in literature]] [[Category:Years of the 18th century in literature]]

{{Year nav topic5|1890|film|television}} {{Years in film}} The decade of the '''1890s in film''' involved some significant events.
==Events== {{stack|[[File:Trafalgar Square 1890 - ten remaining frames by Wordsworth Donisthorpe.gif|thumb|right|Ten remaining frames of London's Trafalgar Square taken by Wordsworth Donisthorpe in 1890]]}} *1890 – [[Wordsworth Donisthorpe]] and [[W. C. Crofts]] film [[London's Trafalgar Square]]<ref>{{citation |first=Paul T |last=Burns |title=The History of The Discovery of Cinematography - 1885–1889 |url=http://www.precinemahistory.net/1885.htm |accessdate=2009-05-10}} and {{citation |title=Ten Remaining Frames Of Donisthorpe's 1890 'Trafalgar Square' Footage Come To Life |url=http://www.precinemahistory.net/images/trafalgarsquare_animation_small.gif |format=GIF |accessdate=2009-05-10}}</ref> using a camera patented in 1889.<ref>{{Citation|author=Herbert, S.|year=1998|title=Industry, Liberty, and a Vision: Wordsworth Donisthorpe's Kinesigraph|publisher=[[The Projection Box]]|location=London|isbn=0-9523941-3-8}}</ref> *1891 – Following the work of [[Eadweard Muybridge]], [[Étienne-Jules Marey]], and [[George Eastman]], Thomas Edison employee [[William K. L. Dickson]] finishes work on a motion-picture camera and a viewing machine called the [[Kinetoscope]]. *May 20, 1891 – [[Thomas Edison]] holds the first public presentation of his Kinetoscope for the National Federation of Women's Clubs. *August 24, 1891 – Edison files for a patent of the Kinetoscope. *1892 – In France, [[Charles-Émile Reynaud]] began to have public screenings in Paris at the [[Théâtre Optique]], with hundreds of drawings on a reel that he wound through his [[Zoetrope]] projector to construct moving images that continued for 15 minutes. *1892 – The [[Eastman Company]] becomes the [[Eastman Kodak Company]]. *March 14, 1893 – Edison is granted Patent #493,426 for "An Apparatus for Exhibiting Photographs of Moving Objects" (the Kinetoscope). *1893 – Edison builds a motion-picture studio near his laboratory, dubbed the "Black Maria" by his staff. *May 9, 1893 – In America, Edison holds the first public exhibition of films shot using his [[Kinetograph]] at the [[Brooklyn Museum|Brooklyn Institute]]. Unfortunately, only one person at a time could use his Kinetoscope viewing machine. *January 7, 1894 – Edison films his assistant, [[Fred Ott]] [[Fred Ott's Sneeze|sneezing]] with the Kinetoscope at the "Black Maria". *April 14, 1894 – The first commercial presentation of the Kinetoscope takes place in the Holland Brothers' Kinetoscope Parlor at 1155 Broadway, New York City. *1894 – Kinetoscope viewing parlors begin to open in major cities. Each parlor contains several machines. *1895 – In France, brothers named [[Auguste and Louis Lumière]] design and build a lightweight, hand-held motion picture camera called the [[Cinématographe]]. The brothers discover that their machine can also be used to project images onto a large screen. They create several short films at this time that are considered to be pivotal in the history of motion pictures. *November 1895 – In Germany, [[Max Skladanowsky|Emil and Max Skladanowsky]] develop their own film projector. *December 1895 – In France, the Lumière brothers hold their first public screening of films shot with their Cinématographe. *January 1896 – In Britain, [[Birt Acres]] and [[Robert W. Paul]] develop their own film projector, the [[Theatrograph]] (later known as the [[Animatograph]]). *January 1896 – In the United States, a projector called the [[Vitascope]] is designed by [[Charles Francis Jenkins]] and [[Thomas Armat]]. Armat begins to work with Edison to manufacture the [[Vitascope]], which projects motion pictures. *April 1896 – Edison and Armat's Vitascope is used to project motion pictures in public screenings in New York City. *1896 – French magician and filmmaker [[Georges Méliès]] begins experimenting with the new motion picture technology, developing many early [[special effect]]s techniques, including stop-motion photography. *1896 – [[Pathé|Pathé-Frères]] is founded. *1897 – A total of 125 people die during a film screening at the Charity Bazaar in Paris after a curtain catches on fire from the ether used to fuel the projector lamp.
==Births== *January 15, 1891 – [[Arne Weel]] (died [[1975 in film|1975]]) *January 22, 1893 – [[Conrad Veidt]] (died [[1943 in film|1943]]) *April 20, 1893 – [[Harold Lloyd]] (died [[1971 in film|1971]]) *October 4, 1895 – [[Buster Keaton]] (died [[1966 in film|1966]]) *January 3, 1897 – [[Marion Davies]] (died [[1961 in film|1961]]) *September 30, 1898 – [[Renée Adorée]] (died [[1933 in film|1933]])
==Lists of films== {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| * [[1890 in film]] * [[1891 in film]] * [[1892 in film]] * [[1893 in film]] * [[1894 in film]] * [[1895 in film]] * [[1896 in film]] * [[1897 in film]] * [[1898 in film]] * [[1899 in film]] }}
==See also== * [[Film]] * [[History of film]] * [[Lists of films]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:1890s In Film}} [[Category:Films by decade]] [[Category:1890s in film| ]] [[Category:Decades in film]]

{{Italic title}} {{Infobox artwork | image_file = 2014 Columbia University Alma Mater closeup.jpg | painting_alignment = Front | image_size = 267px | caption = (2014) | title = Alma Mater | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = [[Daniel Chester French]] | year = 1903-04 | type = [[Bronze]] | height_imperial = 8.6 | width_imperial = 5.9 | length_imperial = 6.2 | imperial_unit = ft | metric_unit = m | city = [[New York City]] | museum = | coordinates = {{coord|40|48|28.2|N|73|57|43.7|W |display=title |type:landmark_region:US-NY}} |owner = [[Columbia University]] }} '''''Alma Mater''''' is a bronze sculpture of the goddess [[Athena]] by [[Daniel Chester French]] which is located on the steps leading to the [[Low Memorial Library]] on the [[Morningside Heights]] campus of [[Columbia University]] in [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]]. Using [[Audrey Munson]] as a model,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.llnyc.com/43144-meet-the-most-popular-model-in-new-york-youve-never-heard-of|title=Meet the most popular model in New York you've never heard of|date=2016-03-07|language=en-US|access-date=2016-09-02}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://untappedcities.com/2016/04/15/audrey-munson-the-most-visible-new-york-woman-you-dont-know/|title=Untapped Cities|date=2016-04-15|language=en-US|access-date=2016-09-02}}</ref> French designed the statue in 1901 and installed it in September, 1903.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://blogs.cul.columbia.edu/outdoorsculpture/2014/07/15/unveiling-alma-mater/|title=Unveiling Alma Mater {{!}} Public Outdoor Sculpture at Columbia|website=blogs.cul.columbia.edu|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-19}}</ref> It was donated in memory of alumnus [[Robert Goelet]] of the Class of 1860 by his wife, Harriette W. Goelet.<ref name=Richman>Richman, Michael. ''Daniel Chester French: An American Sculptor'' (The Preservation Press, 1976, reprinted 1983), pp. 90–96: discussion of the commission, creation and installation of the sculpture.</ref> ''Alma Mater'' has become a symbol of the university.
An owl, a symbol of knowledge and learning,<ref name=Richman /> is hidden in the folds of ''Alma Mater'''s cloak near her left leg<ref>Durante, Dianne. ''Outdoor Monuments of Manhattan: A Historical Guide'' (New York University Press, 2007), p. 230.</ref> and college superstition has it that the first member of the incoming class to find the owl will become class [[valedictorian]]. The legend at another time was that any Columbia student who found the owl on his first try would marry a girl from [[Barnard College|Barnard]].
When the statue was originally installed it was gilded in gold.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mirrorservice.org/sites/gutenberg.org/3/8/2/6/38267/38267-h/38267-h.htm|title=The Project Gutenburg ebook of International Congress of Arts and Science, 1906, Volume 1, edited by Howard J. Rogers.|last=|first=|date=|website=www.mirrorservice.org|publisher=|language=en|access-date=2017-01-19}}</ref><ref name=":0" /> Over time, the original gilding wore off and the few remaining flakes were removed in 1950.<ref name="20th">{{Cite web|url=http://library.columbia.edu/locations"/cuarchives/resources/almaearly/alma20cent.html|title=Alma Mater: In the 20th Century|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=January 18, 2017}}</ref> In 1962, the University made the decision to have the gilding reapplied; however, the new gilding was removed after protests.<ref name="aia">{{cite aia5}}, p. 497.</ref>
In the early morning hours of May 17, 1970, a bomb was planted on the statue. The resulting explosion caused significant damage to ''Alma Mater's'' throne. The damage remained until 1978, when the statue was removed from Columbia. The throne was recast and the sculpture was cleaned, refinished with a new patina, and returned to the Low steps.<ref name="20th" />
==See also== *[[Alma mater]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{Commonscat-inline|Alma Mater by Daniel Chester French|''Alma Mater'' by Daniel Chester French}} *[http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?&profile=all&source=~!siartinventories&uri=full=3100001~!20526~!0#focus Save Outdoor Sculpture Survey of ''Alma Mater'']

{{Infobox ballet company | name = Arcane Collective | logo = | local_name = | previous_names = | predecessor = | founded = {{Start date|2011}} | founders = [[Morleigh Steinberg]]
[[Oguri]] | founding_director = | founding_choreographers = | founding_person_type = | founding_person_name = | venue = [[Dublin]], Ireland | website = {{URL|http://arcanecollective.com}} | chief_executive = | director = | assistant_director = | coordinator = | company_manager = | ballet_staff_type = | ballet_staff_name = | artistic_director = | deputy_director = | ballet_master_in_chief = | ballet_mistress = | ballet_master = | music_director = | principal_conductor = | choreographers = Liz Roche | artistic_staff_type = | artistic_staff_name = | parent_company = | sister_company = | orchestra = | official_school = | associated_schools = | formation = }} '''Arcane Collective''' is a [[contemporary dance]] production company, producing and presenting work from a [[cooperative]] of international artists from different backgrounds. It was founded in 2011 by [[Morleigh Steinberg]], a dancer and [[choreographer]] and [[Oguri]], a dancer and choreographer from Japan.{{cite web | url=http://articles.latimes.com/2012/may/17/entertainment/la-et-cm-cold-dream-colour-review-20120516 | title=Review: Striking visuals lift 'Cold Dream Colour' at REDCAT | work=Los Angeles Times | accessdate=June 5, 2013 | last=Bleiberg | first=Laura | year=2013}} Their performance ''Cold Dream Colour'' was presented in 2012, as a homage to the important Irish artist [[Louis le Brocquy]], the performance being inspired by his paintings.{{cite web|url=http://www.lhpublicity.ie/arts-culture/cold-dream-colour/ |title=Cold Dream Colour |work=Lindsey Holmes Publicity |accessdate=June 5, 2013 |year=2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303235835/http://www.lhpublicity.ie/arts-culture/cold-dream-colour/ |archivedate=March 3, 2016 }} Morleigh explained "He so often pays homage to different painters, and I thought, for his birthday we could pay homage to him."{{cite web | url=http://www.u2.com/news/article/6337 | title=Cold Dream Colour, US Premiere | work=U2 | accessdate=7 June 2013 | year=2013 }} The music was composed by [[Paul Chavez]] and performed by [[U2]]'s [[The Edge]] with choreography by Liz Roche{{cite web|url=http://www.guggenheim.org/new-york/calendar-and-events/2013/05/12/arcane-collective-cold-dream-colour/1365 |title=Arcane Collective: Cold Dream Colour |first= |last= |work=guggenheim.org |year=2013 |accessdate=June 5, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130510044312/http://www.guggenheim.org/new-york/calendar-and-events/2013/05/12/arcane-collective-cold-dream-colour/1365 |archivedate=May 10, 2013 }} Steinberg, the artistic director of the piece staged a solo dance as well as a duet with her sister Roxanne, wife of Oguri.{{cite web |url= http://www.hotpress.com/politics/frontlines/7258734.html? |title=For A Dancer |first=Adrienne |last=Murphy |work=hotpress.com |year=2013 |accessdate=June 5, 2013}} Excerpts from ''Cold Dream Colour'' were performed at the [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum|Guggenheim Museum]]'s [[Works & Process]] series in New York in 2013 and Irish broadcaster [[John Kelly (Irish broadcaster)|John Kelly]] moderated a discussion of the work with its creators.{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/events/dance/works-and-process-at-the-guggenheim-12278.html | title=Works & Process at the Guggenheim | first=Siobhan | last=Burke | newspaper=[[The New York Times]] | accessdate=6 June 2013}} Collaborating dancers include Cat Westwood, Boaz Barkan, Sherwood Chen, Joyce Lu and Dani Lunn and costume design by Mariad Whisker.{{cite web | url=http://arcanecollective.com/artists/collaborators/ | title=Collaborators | work=Arcane Collective | accessdate=June 6, 2013 | year=2013}} ==Personnel== ===Dancers=== *Roxanne Steinberg *Cat Westwood *Boaz Barkan *Sherwood Chen *Dani Lunn *Joyce Lu *Morleigh Steinberg ===Choreographer=== *Morleigh Steinberg *Oguri ===Musicians=== *[[The Edge]] *[[Paul Chavez]] ===Artists=== *Louis Le Brocquy *Hirrokazu Kosaka *[[Moses Hacmon]] ===Costume designer=== *Mariad Whisker{{cite web|title=Arcane Collective|url=http://arcanecollective.com|accessdate=29 June 2013}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://arcanecollective.com/ Arcane Collective website] {{Portal|Dance}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Arcane Collective}} [[Category:Contemporary dance]] [[Category:Performing groups established in the 2000s]]

[[File:Archphot300.jpg|thumb]] Early '''architectural photographers''' include [[Roger Fenton]], [[Francis Frith]] (Middle East and Britain), [[Samuel Bourne]] (India) and [[Albert Levy (photographer)|Albert Levy]] (United States and Europe). They paved the way for the modern speciality of [[architectural photography]]. Later architectural photography had practitioners such as [[Ezra Stoller]] and [[Julius Shulman]]. Stoller worked mainly on the east coast of America, having graduated with a degree in architecture in the 1930s. Shulman, who was based on the West Coast, became an architectural photographer after some images that he had taken of one of [[Richard Neutra]]'s houses in California made their way onto the architect's desk.
== Notable architectural photographers == {{div col|colwidth=22em}} *[[Berenice Abbott]] *[[Eugène Atget]] *[[James Austin (photographer)|James Austin]] *[[Iwan Baan]] *[[Bernd and Hilla Becher]] * [[Hélène Binet]] (b. 1959)<ref name="Glancey">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2002/apr/15/artsfeatures|title=The dream life of buildings|last=Glancey|first=Jonathan|date=15 April 2002|work=[[The Guardian]]|quote= ..Hélène Binet is one of the world's finest architectural photographers..|accessdate=9 May 2011}}</ref> *[[Jack Boucher]] *[[Sergio Castiglione]] *[[Phyllis Dearborn]] *[[Frederick H. Evans]] *[[Lucien Hervé]] *[[Carol M. Highsmith]] *[[Candida Höfer]] *[[Julien Lanoo]] *[[Bedford Lemere]] *[[Eric de Maré]] *[[Robert J. Massar]] *[[Lucia Moholy]] *[[Andrew Prokos]] *[[Tim Rawle]] *[[Julius Shulman]] *[[Wolfgang Sievers]] *[[G. E. Kidder Smith]] *[[Ezra Stoller]] *[[Wayne Thom]] *[[Pierre Trémaux]] *[[Iwao Yamawaki]]
{{div col end}}

{{Infobox magazine | title = Art-Language | image_file = Art-LanguageV3No1-1974.jpg | editor = [[Joseph Kosuth]], Charles Harrison. | category = Art | publisher = [[Art & Language]] Press | country = United Kingdom | frequency = Triannually | firstdate = 1969 | lastdate = 1985 | website = | oclc = 2243756 | ISSN = | eISSN = }} '''Art-Language The Journal of conceptual art''' (1969-1985) was a [[magazine]] published by the [[conceptual art]]ists of [[Art & Language]]. Involving more than 20 artists, in the [[United States]], [[Europe]] and [[Australia]], and covering almost 20 years production, it is one of the most extensive artworks of conceptual art, and is regarded as an important influence on both conceptual art and [[contemporary art]].
I don't understand quite a good deal of what is said by Art-Language, but I admire the investigatory energies, the tireless spade-work (not calling one one), the full commitment to the reestablishment of a valid language by which to discuss art and the occasional humour in their writings. The chaos in their reasons fascinates me, but it is also irritating to be unequipped to evaluate their work. - ''Six Years: The Dematerialization of the Art Object'', [[Lucy R. Lippard]], 1973.[https://books.google.fr/books?redir_esc=y&hl=fr&id=t2nwiTwd6fwC&q=Art-Language#v=snippet&q=Art-Language&f=false ''Six Years: The Dematerialisation of the Art Object'' - Lucy R. Lippard, New York Praeger, 1973, p151]
==Background== {{Main article|Art & Language}} The name Art & Language is derived form the journal Art-Language that was published by Art & Language Press.[http://www.bbc.co.uk/coventry/culture/stories/2003/04/art-and-language.shtml ''Paying Hommage to Art & Language revolutionaries'', BBC, 2003.][https://www.nts.live/artists/65770-art-language NTS Live, Art & Language] Art & Language Press had been created in 1968 to give a publication arm to the ongoing conversation between the four founders of Art & Language (Michael Baldwin, Terry Atkinson, David Bainbridge, Harold Hurrell), and also between Art & Language and other artists in America or other parts of the world.[https://oac.cdlib.org/findaid/ark:/13030/kt8489r9cw/entire_text/ Art & Language New York Archives, The Getty Museum, Los Angeles][http://d-scholarship.pitt.edu/11494/1/ETD_Template_Robert__Bailey.pdf ''Art & Language'', Robert Bailey, 2012.] Strong connections have been made over time between the British artists of Art & Language and American artists, in 1966, Michael Baldwin who has just been rewarded a Prize from the ''Northern Young Contemporaries'', spent the money on a trip to New York, to meet and discuss with [[Donald Judd]], [[Roy Lichtenstein]], and [[Robert Morris (artist)|Robert Morris]]. In November 1967, thanks to [[Robert Smithson]], ''arts magazine'', a New York-based magazine, published for the first time a text-work of Art & Language (before the foundation of the group) titled ''Remarks on Air-Conditioning, an Extravaganza of Blandness'' written by Michael Baldwin. It is interesting to note Michael Baldwin is presented as an English writer and an artist concerned with the non-exhibition.''Remarks on Air-Conditioning An Extravaganza of Blandness'', Michael Baldwin, arts magazine, November 1967.[https://books.google.fr/books?id=P1gqDAAAQBAJ&pg=PT153&lpg=PT153&dq=Art-Language+journal+of+conceptual+art&source=bl&ots=ATzAqpYGKQ&sig=iUEjz5feOk8mlWwmeC3Fsl5hgyI&hl=fr&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjChMDNjZrdAhWMCsAKHajNB6w4PBDoATACegQIBxAB#v=onepage&q=Art-Language%20journal%20of%20conceptual%20art&f=false ''Art & Language International'', Robert Bailey, 2016.] In 1969, ''Art Press'', was produced in New York by Ian Burn and Mel Ramsden. In it they published their own text-works as well as items by [[Adrian Piper]], [[Sol LeWitt]] and [[Stephen Kaltenbach]].[http://www.leftmatrix.com/july69lewitt.html ''July 1969'' - Ian Burn, Mel Ramsden, Art Press, The Society for Theoretical Art and Analyses, New York, July 1969] ==History== ===Art-Language=== Art-Language The Journal of conceptual art was published by [[Art & Language|Art & Language Press]],[http://bibliothequekandinsky.centrepompidou.fr/clientBookline/service/reference.asp?INSTANCE=INCIPIO&OUTPUT=PORTAL&DOCID=0468760&DOCBASE=CGPP ''Art-Language'', Centre Pompidou.] it is regarded as an important influence on both conceptual art and contemporary art.[https://www.flashartonline.com/article/art-language/ ''Art & Language The Unfinished Legacy'', Fernando Frances, Flash Art, February 2011][https://www.artspace.com/magazine/art_101/art_market/6-most-important-artist-run-magazines-53346 6 most important artist run magazines, Maya Harakawa, December 2015, artspace.com][https://arthist.net/archive/16167 Looking at Art_Language] Art & Language Press was founded at the same time as an art practice under the name Art & Language in 1968 by four artists, Michael Baldwin, Terry Atkinson, Harold Hurrell, and David Bainbridge.[http://chicagoartmagazine.com/2010/02/art-language-comes-to-rhona-hoffman-gallery/ Art & Language comes to Rhona Hoffman] They were also the editors of the first volume published in May 1969.[https://edcat.net/item/art-language-vol-1-no-1-may-1969/ Art-Language Vol.1 Nr.1] Terry Atkinson spent the summer of 1969 with Joseph Kosuth in New York, and in August of that year, Joseph Kosuth became the American editor of Art-Language.''Status and priority'' - Michael Baldwin, Terry Atkinson, David Bainbridge, Harold Hurrell, Studio International 179, January 1970 From the second volume, the journal was edited both in the [[United Kingdom]] and in the [[United States]],[https://www.jstor.org/stable/10.1086/509748?seq=1#page_scan_tab_contents|title= Reflections on conceptual art Voices Off, Critical Inquiry] Essays by members of Art & Language appeared regularly in Studio International, and in February 1970, the general editor and art critic [[Charles Townsend Harrison|Charles Harrison]] published an article titled ''Notes Towards Art Work'', arguing that ″The only alternative to criticism is art″.''Notes Towards Art Work'' - Charles Harrison, Studio International 180, February 1970 In 1971, having resigned from Studio International, he became the general editor of Art-Language. In 1971, Terry Atkinson had also met Ian Burn and Mel Ramsden in New York in 1969 and, having published a number of text-works as the ''Society for Theoretical Art and Analyses'', they joined with Art-Language that year.[http://www.leftmatrix.com/artlanguage.html ''Art & Language'', leftmatrix.com]''We are cell arent we?: Art & Language and the Documenta Index - William Wood, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, October 1992 At the same time in Coventry, David Rushton, Philip Pilkington and Graham Howard, three ''Art Theory'' students of Baldwin, Bainbridge and Atkinson began to work under the name of Art & Language. In that year ''Coventry College of Art'' was transformed into the ''Faculty of Art and Design'', part of ''Lanchester Polytechnic''.[https://www.coventrytelegraph.net/news/coventry-news/gallery/coventry-university-celebrates-175th-birthday-14690150 ''Coventry University celebrates 175th Birthday'', Laura Hartley, Coventry telegraph, May 2018] The new dean of the faculty, saw it as his task to bring an end to the ''Art-Theory'' course.
In the summer of 1971, the Art-Theory course was dismantled by arbitrary exercise of power and Baldwin and Bainbridge dismissed along with some other members of the part-time staff. Atkinson remained. His presence enabled ther authorities in charge to claim some credibility for the ruins ... Art & Language found itself in exile from any official academic or educational context … Art & Language work in all its forms was addressed first and foremost to ‘art’ as discourse, rather than to the enlargement of the extensive category of art objects - ''A Provisional History of Art & Language'', Charles Harrison and Fred Orton, Editions E. Fabre, Paris 1982, pp. 26-27
Michael Baldwin and Terry Atkinson wrote an extensive 25 pages critical essay on Art education in an article titled ''Art Teaching'' and published it in Art-Language Volume 1 Number 4. In 1973, Atkinson eventually resigned.
In virtue of this prototype of present art-school sensibility, William Morris and his followers have helped spawn the resolute craftsmanship bias in British art education in the earlier part of the century. Of course this is not to say that Morris' influence stopped at Lowestoft and the Wash; the Bauhaus founders had a good look at Morris -and there may yet be a case for looking at the Bauhaus as the definitive example in showing how ″fine art″ and ″design″ do diverge.''Art Teaching'', Terry Atkinson and Michael Baldwin, Art-Language Volume 1 Number 4, November 1971
While, in 1972, the activity of Art & Language was exclusively textual and its identity somehow confounded with Art-Language, the production of the ''Index 01'', for the [[Documenta 5]], under the name of ''The Art & Language Institute'' marked a shift.''We are cell aren't we?: Art & Language and the Documenta Index - William Wood, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, October 1992 From Art-Language Volume 2 Number 3, the journal became anonymous and the authorship of the texts weren't given anymore to individuals. The journal continued to be published until 1985, and the implications of the indexes of 1972-3 persisted in bearing in various ways – and to a greater and lesser extent upon its content. A new series appeared in 1994, continuing for 3 issues until 1999. Apart from Baldwin, Ramsden and Harrison, into whose hands the work of Art & Language had been taken by 1976, its contributors included Philip Pilkington and Paul Wood. ''Further Essays on Art & Language'', Charles Harrison , The MIT Press, Cambridge Massachusetts, 2001 ===Editors=== The first number was edited by Art & Language, Joseph Kosuth became the American editor from August 1969 until 1972, and Art & Language remained the English editors. In 1971, Charles Harrison became the general editor of Art-Language, and he remained so until the last volume. ===Distributors=== * United Kingdom: Art & Language, [[Lisson Gallery]], Robert Self Publications, Arts Bibliographic. * United States of America: Joseph Kosuth, Ian Burn, Mel Ramsden, [[Kathryn Bigelow]], [[Printed Matter, Inc.]]. ==Complete list and contributors== The authors of the articles are named in the first 7 issues of the journal, and from 1974, all texts are collectively attributed to Art & Language. But, since during the internal problems that the group encountered between 1975 and 1976, the name Art & Language remained in the hands of Michael Baldwin, Mel Ramsden and Charles Harrison, it is logical to give them the authorship of the texts from Volume 3 Number 4. * ''Art-Language The Journal of conceptual art Vol.1 Nr.1'' - Sol LeWitt, Dan Graham, Lawrence Weiner, David Bainbridge, Michael Baldwin - May 1969 * ''Art-Language Vol.1 Nr.2'' - Joseph Kosuth, David Bainbridge, Michael Baldwin, Frederic Barthelme, Stephen McKenna, Robert Brown, David Hirons, Terry Atkinson, Harold Hurrell, Michael Thompson, Mel Ramsden - February 1970 * ''Art-Language Vol.1 Nr.3'' - Ian Burn, Roger Cuthforth, Graham J. Howard, B. Bihari, Mel Ramsden - June 1970 * ''Art-Language Vol.1 Nr.4'' - Stuart Knight, Graham J. Howard, Terry Atkinson, Michael Baldwin - November 1971 * ''Art-Language Vol.2 Nr.1'' - Ian Burn, David Rushton, Graham J. Howard, Terry Atkinson, Michael Baldwin, Mel Ramsden, Philip Pilkington, Kevin Lole - February 1972 * ''Art-Language Vol.2 Nr.2'' - Ian Burn, Terry Atkinson, Michael Baldwin, Mel Ramsden, Harold Hurrell, David Bainbridge, Victor Burgin - Summer 1972 * ''Art-Language Vol.2 Nr.3'' - Ian Burn, Philip Pilkington, David Rushton, Michael Corris, Graham J. Howard, John F. Hemmings, David Bainbridge, Mel Ramsden - September 1973 * ''Art-Language Vol.2 Nr.4'' - Art & Language - June 1974 * ''Art-Language Vol.3 Nr.1'' - Art & Language - September 1974 * ''Art-Language Vol.3 Nr.2'' - Art & Language - May 1975 * ''Art-Language Vol.3 Nr.3'' - Art & Language - June 1976 * ''Art-Language Vol.3 Nr.4'' - Art & Language - October 1976 * ''Art-Language Vol.4 Nr.1'' - Art & Language - May 1977 * ''Art-Language Vol.4 Nr.2'' - Art & Language - October 1977 * ''Art-Language Vol.4 Nr.3'' - Art & Language - October 1978 * ''Art-Language Vol.4 Nr.4'' - Art & Language - June 1980 * ''Art-Language Vol.5 Nr.1'' - Art & Language - October 1982 * ''Art-Language Vol.5 Nr.2'' - Art & Language - March 1984 * ''Art-Language Vol.5 Nr.3'' - Art & Language - March 1985 * ''Art-Language'' New serie Number 1 - Art & Language - June 1994 * ''Art-Language'' New serie Number 2 - Art & Language - June 1997 * ''Art-Language'' New serie Number 3 - Art & Language - September 1999 ==Critical review== *Daniel Buren:
To lend support to their pseudo-cultural references and to their bluffing games, with a complacent display of questionable scholarship, certain artists attempt to explain what conceptual art would be, could be or should be -thus making a conceptual work. There is no lack of vulgarity in pretense. In place of unpretentious inquiry we are subjected to a hodgepodge of explanations and justifications which serve as obfuscation in the attempt to convince us of the existence of thought. For these, conceptual art has become ''verbiage art''. They are no longer living in the twentieth century but wish to revive the eighteenth.''Art Conceptuel Formes Conceptuelles'' - Christian Schlatter, Galerie 1900-2000, Paris, 1990, p410-433
* Jeff Wall:
By putting forward its forgotten card-files and print-outs (its caskets of information) conceptualism recapitulates a kind of Mallarméan aesthetic: social subjects are presented as enigmatic hieroglyphs and given the authority of the crypt. The identification of bureaucracy, publicity and academicism with cryptic utterances expresses an awareness of the participation of universities and bureaucracies in a corporate death-machine, an awareness which of course animated the student movement. - Jeff Wall, 1981.''A Draft for Dan Graham's Kammerspiel'', Jeff Wall, 1981.
* Lucy Lippard:
I don't understand quite a good deal of what is said by Art-Language, but I admire the investigatory energies, the tireless spade-work (not calling one one), the full commitment to the reestablishment of a valid language by which to discuss art and the occasional humour in their writings. The chaos in their reasons fascinates me, but it is also irritating to be unequipped to evaluate their work. I don't know how it is or if it is evaluated by adepts in philosophy as philosophy, but I find it infuriating to have to take them on faith. - ''Six Years: The Dematerialization of the Art Object'', [[Lucy R. Lippard]], 1973.[https://books.google.fr/books?redir_esc=y&hl=fr&id=t2nwiTwd6fwC&q=Art-Language#v=snippet&q=Art-Language&f=false ''Six Years: The Dematerialisation of the Art Object'' - Lucy R. Lippard, New York Praeger, 1973, p151]
==Selected Exhibitions== * ''Information'', [[Museum of Modern Art]], New York, 1970. * ''The British Avant-Garde'', New York Cultural Center, New York, 1971. * ''[[Documenta 5]]'', [[Fridericianum|Museum Fridericianum]], Kassel, 1972. * ''Projekt 74'', Cologne, 1974. * ''Un Certain Art Anglais'', [[Musée d'Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris]], Paris, 1979. * ''L'art conceptuel, une perspective'', Musée d'Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris, Paris, Fundacion Caja de Pensiones, Madrid, [[Deichtorhallen]], Hamburg, 1989. * ''Reconsidering the Object of Art, 1965-1975'', [[Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles]], Los Angeles, 1995. * ''Collective Creativity'', Kunsthalle Fridericianum, Kassel, 2005. * ''Materialising ″Six Years″: Lucy Lippard and the Emergence of Conceptual Art'', [[Brooklyn Museum]], New York, 2012. * ''Art & Language Uncompleted: The [[Philippe Méaille|Philippe Méaille Collection]]'', [[MACBA]], Barcelona, 2014. * ''Art & Language: Reality (Dark) Fragments (Light)'', [[Château de Montsoreau-Museum of Contemporary Art]], Montsoreau, 2018. ==Collections== * [[Château de Montsoreau-Museum of Contemporary Art]], Montsoreau.[http://www.chateau-montsoreau.com/wordpress/fr/100-chateau-100-contemporain/la-collection/] * [[National Gallery of Victoria]], Melbourne.[https://www.ngv.vic.gov.au/explore/collection/work/89243/] * [[Centre Georges Pompidou]], Paris.[http://bibliothequekandinsky.centrepompidou.fr/clientBookline/service/reference.asp?INSTANCE=INCIPIO&OUTPUT=PORTAL&DOCID=0468760&DOCBASE=CGPP] * [[Tate Modern]], London.[https://www.tate.org.uk/research/publications/tate-papers/27/art-and-language] * [[Stedelijk Museum]], Amsterdam.[https://www.stedelijk.nl/en/collection/16193-art-and-language-art-language-:-the-journal-of-conceptual-art] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Artists' books|state=collapsed}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Art-Language The Journal of conceptual art}} [[Category:British art]] [[Category:Artists' books]] [[Category:Conceptual art]] [[Category:Contemporary art]] [[Category:1969 books]]

Founded in 2015, the '''CTG Collective''' is a not-for-profit organization focusing on exploring the human experience through boundless configurations of art.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://artzealous.com/in-conversation-with-catinca-tabacaru-of-ctg-collective/|title=In Conversation with Catinca Tabacaru of CTG Collective|last=Miller|first=Katita|date=2017-05-16|website=Art Zealous|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-09-16}}</ref>
== History == The Collective was founded by Rachel Monosov, [[Catinca Tabacaru Gallery|Catinca Tabacaru]] and Justin Orvis Steimer, which has been running international traveling residencies since 2015.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=|title=On the artistic side, international sculpture project on permanet display on Pool's Island|last=|first=|date=2016-08-25|work=The Beacon Canada|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
==List of residencies== CTG(R): ZImbabwe, 2015<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.ctgcollective.com/ctg-r-zimbabwe|title=CTG(R): Zimbabwe, 2015|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-09-16}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://www.herald.co.zw/zig-zag-arts-project-comes-to-zim/|title=Zig Zag Project comes to Zim|last=|first=|date=2016-04-11|website=The Herald Zimbabwe|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-09-16}}</ref> * Participants: Virginia Chihota, Admire Kamudzengerere, Rachel Monosov, Terrence Musekiwa, Gareth Nyandoro, Xavier Robles de Medina, Justin Orvis Steimer CTG(R): NewFoundland, 2016<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ctgcollective.com/ctg-r-newfoundland|title=CTG(R): Newfoundland, 2016|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-09-16}}</ref> * Participants: Rachel Monosov, Terrence Musekiwa, Yapci Ramos and Justin Orvis Steimer, in collaboration with Pool’s Island descendent Matthew Evans
==Exhibitions== * 1972: Rachel Monosov and Admire Kamudzengerere * TERRA NOVA: Rachel Monosov, Terrence Musekiwa, Yapci Ramos, Justin Orvis Steimer<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://quietlunch.com/terra-nova-at-catinca-tabacaru-gallery/|title=CONVERSATIONS WITH THE WIND. {{!}} TERRA NOVA AT CATINCA TABACARU GALLERY.|last=|first=|date=2017-05-25|website=Quiet Lunch|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-09-16}}</ref><ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> * Zig Zag Zim: Part II: Admire Kamudzengerere, Rachel Monosov, Terrence Musekiwa, Xavier Robles de Medina, Justin Orvis Steimer<ref name=":3" /> * Zig Zag Zim: Virginia Chihota, Admire Kamudzengerere, Rachel Monosov, Terrence Musekiwa, Xavier Robles de Medina, Justin Orvis Steimer<ref name=":3" /> * National Gallery of Zimbabwe, Harare (2016)<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":2" />
==Reference== <references /> ==External Links== * [https://www.ctgcollective.com/about CTG Collective Website] * [http://www.catincatabacaru.com/collective Catinca Tabacaru Gallery website]

revision.text:
[[Image:Andrea Mantegna - Ceiling Oculus - WGA14021.jpg|thumb|right|The ''di sotto in sù'' ceiling panel of the Camera picta.]] [[Image:Andrea Mantegna 054.jpg|thumb|right|The "Court Scene".]]
The '''Camera degli Sposi''' ("bridal chamber"), sometimes known as the '''Camera picta''' ("painted chamber"), is a room [[fresco]]ed with [[illusionistic painting]]s by [[Andrea Mantegna]] in the [[Ducal Palace, Mantua]], [[Italy]].<ref name="radke">{{cite book|first=John T.|last=Paoletti|author2=Gary M. Radke|title=Art, Power, and Patronage in Renaissance Italy|location=[[Upper Saddle River]]|publisher=[[Pearson PLC|Pearson]]/[[Prentice Hall]] |year=2005|pages=356–359}}.</ref><ref name="adams">{{cite book|first= Laurie |last=Schneider Adams|title=Italian Renaissance Art|location=[[Boulder]]|publisher=[[Westview Press]]|year=2001|pages=262–267}}.</ref> It was painted between 1465 and 1474 and commissioned by [[Ludovico III Gonzaga, Marquis of Mantua|Ludovico III Gonzaga]], and is notable for the use of ''[[trompe l'oeil]]'' details and its ''[[di sotto in sù]]'' ceiling. [[Image:Andrea Mantegna 080.jpg|thumb|left|The "Meeting Scene".]]
The chronological sequence of the paintings has been recently discovered: the painter started from the vault by dry painting in the background small bits particularly those of the oculus and the wreath surrounding it. Then he moved on to the ‘Court scene’ where he used a mysterious oily tempera dry laid out on the surface. The east and south walls followed, with the traditional fresco technique representing heavy curtains. Finally the ‘Meeting scene’ on the west wall was painted, always ‘a fresco’ but in very small bits which confirms an almost ten-year period of work on that part of the chamber.<ref name="guidemantova">{{cite web |url=http://guideturistichemantova.it/English/?p=34 |title=Mantua Tourist Guide, The Bridal Chamber |accessdate=4 April 2011 }}.</ref>
==The walls== The "Court Scene" on the north wall shows Ludovico Gonzaga, dressed informally, with his wife [[Barbara of Brandenburg, Marquise of Mantua|Barbara of Brandenburg]]. They are seated with their relatives, while a group of [[courtier]]s fill the rest of the wall. The figures are interacting in an illusionistically expanded space.
On the west wall is the "Meeting scene". This fresco shows Ludovico in official robes in an ideal meeting with his son, Cardinal Francesco Gonzaga, the [[Holy Roman Emperor]] [[Frederick III, Holy Roman Emperor|Frederick III]] and [[Christian I of Denmark]].
The commission is far from being explained by scholars. The traditional interpretation sees the frescos as linked to the election as Cardinal of Ludovico's son Francesco Gonzaga, which took place on January 1, 1462: the Court scene should then represent the Marquis receiving the news, and the Meeting Scene should see father and son reunited in the happy event.<ref name="guidemantova"/>
The mature and strongly-built figure of Francesco though, doesn’t seem to match with his age in 1461, which was only 17 (an early portrait held today in Naples confirms this). For this reason, these frescos could refer to a later visit of Cardinal Francesco to Mantua, perhaps on August 1472 when he was given the title of St. Andrew.<ref name="guidemantova"/>
==The ceiling== Mantegna's playful ceiling presents an [[oculus]] that illusionistically opens into a blue sky, with foreshortened [[putti]] playfully frolicking around a balustrade. This was one of the earliest [[di sotto in sù]] ceiling paintings.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{commons category|Camera degli Sposi, Palazzo Ducale, Mantua|Camera degli Sposi}} * [http://guideturistichemantova.it/ Mantua tourist guide] Mantua tourist guide
{{coord|45|09|40|N|10|48|00|E|region:IT_type:landmark_source:kolossus-itwiki|display=title}}
{{Andrea Mantegna}} {{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Camera Degli Sposi}} [[Category:1460s paintings]] [[Category:1470s paintings]] [[Category:Paintings by Andrea Mantegna]] [[Category:Fresco paintings]] [[Category:Paintings in Mantua]] [[Category:Angels in art]] [[Category:Birds in art]]

{{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = <!--{{PAGENAME}} by default--> | synonym = | image = Lateral surface of cerebral cortex - gyri.png | image_size = | alt = | caption = Lateral surface of cerebral cortex | pronounce = | specialty = <!-- from Wikidata, can be overwritten --> | symptoms = | complications = | onset = | duration = | types = | causes = | risks = | diagnosis = | differential = | prevention = | treatment = | medication = | prognosis = | frequency = | deaths = }} '''Cerebral achromatopsia''' is a type of color-blindness caused by damage to the [[cerebral cortex]] of the brain, rather than abnormalities in the cells of the eye's [[retina]]. It is often confused with congenital [[achromatopsia]]<ref name=Fulton>Briefing from 2008 Achromatopsia Conference by James Fulton</ref> but underlying physiological deficits of the disorders are completely distinct. A similar, but distinct, deficit called '''color agnosia''' exists in which a person has intact color perception (as measured by a matching task) but has deficits in color recognition, such as knowing which color they are looking at.
==Signs and symptoms==
Patients with cerebral achromatopsia deny having any experience of color when asked and fail standard clinical assessments like the [[Farnsworth-Munsell 100 hue test|Farnsworth-Munsell 100-hue test]] (a test of color ordering with no naming requirements). Patients may often [[Anosognosia|not notice their loss of color vision]] and merely describe the world they see as being "drab". Most describe seeing the world in "shades of gray".<ref name=Jaeger/> This observation notes a key difference between cerebral and congenital achromatopsia, as those born with achromatopsia have never had an experience of color or gray.
==Pathophysiology==
Cerebral achromatopsia differs from other forms of color blindness in subtle but important ways. It is a consequence of cortical damage that arises through [[ischemia]] or [[infarction]] of a specific area in the ventral occipitotemporal cortex of humans.<ref name=Jaeger>{{cite journal |vauthors=Jaeger W, Krastel H, Braun S |title=[Cerebral achromatopsia (symptoms, course, differential diagnosis and strategy of the study). I] |language=German |journal=Klin Monbl Augenheilkd |volume=193 |issue=6 |pages=627–34 |date=December 1988 |pmid=3265459 |doi=10.1055/s-2008-1050309 |url=}}</ref> This damage is almost always the result of injury or illness.<ref name="Bouvier SE, 2006"/>
===Classification=== A 2005 study examined 92 case studies since 1970 in which cerebral lesions affected color vision.<ref name="Bouvier SE, 2006"/> The severity and size of the visual field affected in cerebral achromatopsiacs vary from patient to patient.
====Bilateral and hemifield====
The majority of cases in the 2005 study were the result of bilateral lesions in the ventral occipital cortex.<ref name="Bouvier SE, 2006"/> It is unknown whether this was the result of bilateral lesions being more likely to produce color-loss symptoms, or if it was a sampling effect of patients with more severe brain trauma more often being admitted for treatment. In many of the cases examined, patients reported only partial loss of color vision. The locations of color vision loss can be restricted to one hemisphere or one quarter of the visual field. The term "hemiachromatopsia" has been used to denote patients who experience loss of color in only one hemisphere of the visual field. However, as applied to achromatopia resulting from brain trauma, the term is incomplete in characterizing the often-complex nature of the vision loss.
====Transient====
In still rarer cases, temporary ischemia of the associated ventral occipital cortex can result in transient achromatopsia. The condition has thus far been characterized only in stroke patients and provides further support for a color processing area.
In one case, a 78-year-old stroke victim had lost the ability to identify color, but was unaware of his deficit until doctors performed color discretion tests.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=von Arx SW, Müri RM, Heinemann D, Hess CW, Nyffeler T |title=Anosognosia for cerebral achromatopsia--a longitudinal case study |journal=Neuropsychologia |volume=48 |issue=4 |pages=970–7 |date=March 2010 |pmid=19944708 |doi=10.1016/j.neuropsychologia.2009.11.018 |url=}}</ref> Even when presented with this information, the patient believed he had retained his ability to perceive color even though the world around him appeared grey. He attributed this achromatism to "poor lighting" and it took several weeks for the patient to fully appreciate the extent of his disability. In addition, the characteristic comorbidity of prosopagnosia was present. After two months and frequent sessions with doctors, tests indicated his color had fully returned. The ischemia caused by lesions on the posterior cerebral arteries had subsided and follow up MRI scans indicated that blood flow had once again returned to the VOC.
===Co-occurrence with other deficits=== The most common disorder seen alongside cerebral achromatopsia is [[prosopagnosia]], the inability to recognize or recall faces. In some studies, the comorbidity is seen as high as 72%.<ref name="Bouvier SE, 2006"/> This significance has not been overlooked and is a subject of ongoing research. See {{section link||Difference from congenital achromatopsia}} below.
Cerebral achromatopsiacs often have poor spatial acuity.<ref name="Bouvier SE, 2006"/>
==Diagnosis==
The most common tests perform to diagnose cerebral achromatopsia are the [[Farnsworth-Munsell 100 hue test]], the [[Ishihara plate]] test, and the color-naming test.<ref name="Bouvier SE, 2006"/> Testing and diagnosis for cerebral achromatopsia is often incomplete and misdiagnosed in doctor’s offices.<ref name=Fulton/>
Remarkably, almost 50% of tested patients diagnosed with cerebral achromatopsia are able to perform normally on the color-naming test. However, these results are somewhat in question because of the sources from which many of these reports come.<ref name="Bouvier SE, 2006"/> Only 29% of cerebral achromatopsia patients successfully pass the Ishihara plate test, which is a more accepted and more standardized test for color blindness.<ref name="Bouvier SE, 2006"/>
===Difference from congenital achromatopsia=== The most apparent distinguishing characteristic between congenital achromatopsia and cerebral achromatopsia is the sudden onset of color vision loss following a severe head injury or damage to the occipital lobe following a stroke or similar ischemic event.<ref name=Jaeger/> Non-invasive imaging techniques can be the most helpful in determining whether the area of damage following a traumatic event is an correlated with color-vision processing. Simple diagnostic tools can also be used to determine whether a patient is a likely candidate for further testing, as advancing imaging procedures can often prove expensive and unnecessary.
Co-morbid factors can be valuable indicators of the likelihood of cerebral achromatoptsia. One disorder often seen alongside cerebral achromatopsia is prosopagnosia, the inability to recall or recognize faces. The correlation is still the subject of ongoing research, but the most telltale clue in this association is the close proximity of brain lesions seen in prosopagnosics and cerebral achromatopsiacs without prosopagnosia.<ref name="Bouvier SE, 2006"/> Figure 1 illustrates overlap of brain lesions compiled from numerous case reports of both disorders. A common area of damage associated with both disorders can be seen in the right occipital lobe.
==Treatment==
No current treatment is known for the disorder. ==History==
The number of reported cases of cerebral achromatopsia are relatively few compared with other forms of color-vision loss. In addition, the severity of the color perception deficits along with other psychological effects vary between patients.<ref name="Bouvier SE, 2006">{{cite journal |vauthors=Bouvier SE, Engel SA |title=Behavioral deficits and cortical damage loci in cerebral achromatopsia |journal=Cereb. Cortex |volume=16 |issue=2 |pages=183–91 |date=February 2006 |pmid=15858161 |doi=10.1093/cercor/bhi096 |url=}}</ref>
==Current research==
Based on the knowledge gained from cerebral achromatopsia case studies, current research is focusing on learning more about the cortical area involved in color processing.
A recent study provided some of the first direct evidence of color-specific processing in the ventral occipital cortex. A subject with a history of seizure activity was examined using fMRI and electrode implantation.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Murphey DK, Yoshor D, Beauchamp MS |title=Perception matches selectivity in the human anterior color center |journal=Curr. Biol. |volume=18 |issue=3 |pages=216–20 |date=February 2008 |pmid=18258428 |doi=10.1016/j.cub.2008.01.013 |url=}}</ref> Using the fMRI, researchers examined the areas of blood oxygenation in the occipital lobe as the subject viewed various color-specific stimuli. The result of the experiment was the identification of an area in the subject, slightly anterior to the lesioned area in cerebral achromatic patients, that responded to variance in color stimulation. The resolution of the MRI was a limiting factor in identifying areas corresponding to specific colors. The next portion of the study used an electrode implanted in the right hemisphere in the location identified by the fMRI scan as pertaining to color processing. It was found the electrical activity of the area increased when the subject was presented with blue stimuli. The next, and most significant finding of the study, was that when the electrode was used to present an electrical stimulus in the subject’s brain, the subject reported the perception of the color blue. Such a result is consistent with other reports of electrical stimulation in visual field maps eliciting perception of phosphines in subjects’ visual field.
The color stimulus presented is not the only factor in determining the involvement of the VOC in color processing.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Beauchamp MS, Haxby JV, Jennings JE, DeYoe EA |title=An fMRI version of the Farnsworth-Munsell 100-Hue test reveals multiple color-selective areas in human ventral occipitotemporal cortex |journal=Cereb. Cortex |volume=9 |issue=3 |pages=257–63 |year=1999 |pmid=10355906 |doi=10.1093/cercor/9.3.257 |url=}}</ref> The amount of attention and the type of object also affect the activiation of the VOC. It has been noted that this area of the occipital lobe may not be a processing center but rather a pathway that is a critical intersection of several cortical areas involved in color perception.
==Society and culture==
The disorder is often presented as evidence of our incomplete knowledge of color processing. Color vision research is a well-studied field of modern neuroscience and the underlying anatomical processing in the retina have been well categorized. The presence of another factor in the perception of color by humans illustrates the need for more research.
===The case of the colorblind painter===
The most famous instance of cerebral achromatopsia is that of "Jonathan I." immortalized in a case study by [[Oliver Sacks]] and Robert Wasserman, and published as "The Case of the Colorblind Painter".<ref>Sacks, Oliver. "The Case of the Colorblind Painter". ''An Anthropologist on Mars''. New York: Random House, 1995. 3-41.</ref> The essay tracks Johnathan I.'s experience with cerebral achromatopsia from the point where an injury to his occipital lobe leaves him without the ability to perceive color, through his subsequent struggles to adapt to a black, white and gray world, and finally to his acceptance and even gratitude for his condition. Especially pertinent is the analysis of how cerebral achromatopsia affects his practice as a painter and artist. Descriptions of cerebral achromatopsia's effects on his psychological health and visual perception are especially striking. For instance, in recounting Mr. I.'s descriptions of flesh and foods, the authors write:
{{quote|Mr. I. could hardly bear the changed appearances of people ("like animated gray statues") any more than he could bear his own changed appearance in the mirror: he shunned social intercourse and found sexual intercourse impossible. He saw people's flesh, his wife's flesh, his own flesh, as an abhorrent gray; "flesh-colored" now appeared "rat-colored" to him. This was so even when he closed his eyes, for his preternaturally vivid ("eidetic") visual imagery was preserved but now without color, and forced on him images, forced him to "see" but see internally with the wrongness of his achromatopsia. He found foods disgusting in their grayish, dead appearance and had to close his eyes to eat. But this did not help very much, for the mental image of a tomato was as black as its appearance.}}
==See also==
*[[Achromatopsia]] *[[Cortical blindness]] *[[Color blindness]] *[[Ishihara color test]]

'''Cherie Bennett''' (born 1960 in [[Buffalo, New York]]) is an American novelist, actress, director, playwright, newspaper columnist, singer, and television writer on the [[CBS Daytime]] [[soap opera]] ''[[The Young and the Restless]]''.
==Biography== Writing was not Bennett's early focus. Sometimes known as the "Big and Tall Barbie Doll", she attended [[Wayne State University]], and then the [[University of Michigan]] in the early 1980s, as a musical theater major. She worked frequently as an actress, doing national musical tours, regional theater productions including [[Mark Medoff|Mark Medoff's]] ''When You Comin' Back, Red Ryder?'' and a well-reviewed turn in the [[off-Broadway]] revival of [[Tennessee Williams|Tennessee Williams']] ''Twenty-Seven Wagons Full of Cotton''. She headed her own [[Improvisational theatre|improv]] comedy trio, Zaniac, and performed as a vocalist, singing backup for [[John Mellencamp]] and in her play, ''Honk Tonk Angels''.
Bennett's favorite non-writing activities are reading ([[memoir]]s, medical mysteries, and show-biz stories), film, theater, cooking, politics, and [[Internet]] shopping. She lives in [[Los Angeles]] with her son.
Her pseudonyms are C.J. Anders, and [[Carrie Austen]]. For many years, she wrote frequently with [[Jeff Gottesfeld]], with whom she shared the [[Zoey Dean]] pseudonym.<ref>[http://www.scholastic.com/teachers/contributor/zoey-dean Biography: Zoey Dean]. [[Scholastic Corporation]] (accessed September 20, 2015)</ref>
Her father was a writer for such shows as ''[[The Twilight Zone (1959 TV series)|The Twilight Zone]]'', ''[[Route 66 (TV series)|Route 66]]'', and [[Sid Caesar|Sid Caesar's]] ''Your Show of Shows''.
Since June 2011, she's been the [[Creative Director|Artistic Director]] at Amusings Productions in [[Sherman Oaks]].
==Television credits== ''[[The Young and the Restless]]'' (hired by [[Lynn Marie Latham]]; fired by [[Maria Arena Bell]]) *[[screenwriter|Script Writer]]: December 14, 2006 - December 21, 2007; March 18 - August 19, 2008 *Associate [[Head Writer]]: July 2007 - December 21, 2007; March 18 - July 10, 2008
''[[As the World Turns]]'' (hired by [[Hogan Sheffer]]) * Breakdown Writer: 2005

''[[Another World (TV series)|Another World]]'' * Story Consultant: 1997
''[[Girls Got Game]]'': 2006
''[[Smallville]]'': 2001 - 2002

'''Six Book Series''' *''University Hospital'' *''Wild Hearts'' *''Teen Angels'' *''Trash'' *''Pageant''
'''Other Books''' *''Turn Me On'' (July 2007) *''Girls in Love'' *''Zink'' *''[[Life in the Fat Lane (novel)|Life in the Fat Lane]]'' *''A Heart Divided'' *''[[Anne Frank and Me]]'' *''[[Searching for David's Heart]]''

The '''classical unities''', '''Aristotelian unities''', or '''three unities''' are rules for [[drama]] derived from a passage in [[Aristotle]]'s ''[[Poetics (Aristotle)|Poetics]]''. In their [[neoclassicism|neoclassical]] form they are as follows: #''unity of action'': a play should have one action that it follows, with minimal subplots. #''unity of time'': the action in a play should occur over a period of no more than 24 hours. #''unity of place'': a play should exist in a single physical space and should not attempt to compress geography, nor should the stage represent more than one place. ==Aristotle's unities== Aristotle dealt with the unity of action in some detail, under the general subject of "definition of tragedy", where he wrote: "serious, complete in itself and of a certain magnitude".
Now, according to our definition, Tragedy is an imitation of an action that is complete, and whole, and of a certain magnitude[http://www.sacred-texts.com/cla/ari/poe/poe08.htm Aristotle's ''Poetics'', VII]. … As therefore, in the other imitative arts, the imitation is one when the object imitated is one, so the plot, being an imitation of an action, must imitate one action and that a whole, the structural union of the parts being such that, if any one of them is displaced or removed, the whole will be disjointed and disturbed. For a thing whose presence or absence makes no visible difference, is not an organic part of the whole.[http://www.sacred-texts.com/cla/ari/poe/poe09.htm Aristotle's ''Poetics'', VIII].
His only reference to the time in the fictive world is in a distinction between the [[Epic poetry|epic]] and [[tragedy|tragic]] forms:
Epic poetry agrees with Tragedy in so far as it is an imitation in [[Verse (poetry)|verse]] of characters of a higher type. They differ, in that Epic poetry admits but one kind of metre, and is narrative in form. They differ, again, in their length: for Tragedy endeavours, as far as possible, to confine itself to a single revolution of the sun, or but slightly to exceed this limit; whereas the Epic action has no limits of time.Aristotle's ''Poetics'', V.
Unlike his prescriptive attitude regarding the plot (unity of action), Aristotle here merely remarks on the typical duration of a tragedy's action, and does not suggest any kind of imperative that it always ought to be so. He was writing after the golden age of [[Greek drama]], and many [[Ancient Greece|Greek]] playwrights wrote plays that do not fit within these conventions. Aristotle does not actually mention the neoclassical unity of place at all. However, the prevalent interpretation of his ''Poetics'' during the Middle Ages inclined toward interpreting his comment on time as another "unity". ==European literature== {{refimprove section|date=October 2014}} [[Italy|Italian]] critics of the 16th century, from [[Lodovico Castelvetro]] onwards, and then [[French literature of the 17th century|17th-century French]] critics, proponents of the [[neoclassicism|neoclassical]] movement, both expanded Aristotle's descriptions. The result was to make them into prescriptions for structuring plays. French drama of the 17th century, particularly that of [[Molière]] and [[Jean Racine|Racine]], was highly regular, and [[Pierre Corneille|Corneille]] incurred harsh criticism for departing from the unities in ''[[Le Cid]]''. The [[England|English]] dramatists writing for the [[English Renaissance theatre|Elizabethan and Jacobean stage]] were largely unaware of these structures. By the later 17th century, however, English dramatists (under the influence of French criticism picked up by those in exile during the [[English Interregnum]]) did begin to assess their own plays according to these rules. Thus, [[John Dryden]], among many others, compares the "irregular" [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]] (only two of Shakespeare's plays conform to the unities – ''[[The Comedy of Errors]]'' and ''[[The Tempest]]'') with the "regular" [[Dryden]] in his ''[[Essay of Dramatick Poesie]]'' (1668), and makes use of the unity of time in this passage criticizing [[Shakespearean histories|Shakespeare's history plays]].
... if you consider the Historical Playes of Shakespeare, they are rather so many Chronicles of Kings, or the business many times of thirty or forty years, crampt into a representation of two hours and a half, which is not to imitate or paint Nature, but rather to draw her in miniature, to take her in little; to look upon her through the wrong end of a Perspective, and receive her Images not onely much less, but infinitely more imperfect then the life: this instead of making a Play delightful, renders it ridiculous.Dryden, ''An Essay of Dramatick Poesie'' (1668), para. 56.
However, Dryden declared Shakespeare "incomparable" because of his disregard for convention:
... in most of the irregular Playes of Shakespeare or [[John Fletcher (playwright)|Fletcher]] (for Ben Johnson's are for the most part regular) there is a more masculine fancy and greater spirit in all the writing, then[sic] there is in any of the French.Dryden, ''An Essay of Dramatick Poesie'' (1668), para. 84.
[[Alexander Pope]] criticizes the violation of the unities in his ''[[Dunciad]]''. In the 1728 version of the poem, the goddess Dulness notes that "Time himself stands still at her command,/ Realms shift their place, and Ocean turns to land" (''Dunciad'' 1728, i, 69–70). Additionally, he notes a violation of unity of action, as tragedy and comedy were mixed. [[Samuel Johnson]], too, applied the unities to drama in his ''Prefaces to Shakespeare''. He was well aware that Aristotle had only recommended the unity of action, and knew that rules must serve drama, not vice versa:
Whether Shakespeare knew the unities, and rejected them by design, or deviated from them by happy ignorance, it is, I think, impossible to decide, and useless to inquire. We may reasonably suppose, that, when he rose to notice, he did not want the counsels and admonitions of scholars and critics, and that he at last deliberately persisted in a practice, which he might have begun by chance. As nothing is essential to the fable, but unity of action, and as the unities of time and place arise evidently from false assumptions, and, by circumscribing the extent of the drama, lessen its variety, I cannot think it much to be lamented, that they were not known by him, or not observed: Nor, if such another poet could arise, should I very vehemently reproach him, that his first act passed at Venice, and his next in Cyprus. Such violations of rules merely positive, become the comprehensive genius of Shakespeare…Johnson, ''Preface to his Edition of Shakespeare's Plays (1765),'' ff. a7r–a7v, para. 59.
[[John Pitcher]], in his [[Arden Shakespeare]] Third Series edition of ''[[The Winter's Tale]]'' (2010), argues that Shakespeare was familiar with the unities due to an English translation of ''Poetics'' that became popular around 1608, and that The Winter's Tale is intentionally breaking all the rules. The classical unities were influential in dramatic criticism until [[Victor Hugo]]'s ''[[Hernani (drama)|Hernani]]'' (1830); one of the things that made that play controversial at its debut was its violation of these rules of [[classicism]]. In the Spanish theatrical tradition, there is [[Lope de Vega]]'s ''Arte nuevo de hacer comedias'' of 1609, which is a defense of the new form for writing and representation of [[Spanish Golden Age|Golden Age]] Spanish theatre. Lope's ''Arte nuevo'' is a 389 verse poem which explicitly defends his and other dramaturges, distancing from Aristotelian unities of theatre. ==See also== *[[History of theater]] *[[Theatre technique]] *[[Theatrical constraints]] ==Notes== ==References== * {{cite book |author=Aristotle |authorlink=Aristotle |year=1907 |title=The Poetics of Aristotle |url=http://www.gutenberg.org/etext/1974 |format=Project Gutenberg e-text # 1974 |edition=4th |others=Samuel Henry Butcher (trans.) |publisher=Macmillan |location=London|oclc=3113766}} * {{cite book |author=Dryden, John |authorlink=John Dryden |year=1668 |title=An Essay of Dramatick Poesie |url=http://andromeda.rutgers.edu/~jlynch/Texts/drampoet.html |editor=Jack Lynch (Ed.)|format=Online reprint |location=London |publisher=Henry Harringman |oclc=4969880}} * {{cite book |author=Johnson, Samuel |authorlink=Samuel Johnson |origyear=1765 |year=2005 |title=Mr. Johnson's Preface To his Edition of Shakespear's Plays |url=https://tspace.library.utoronto.ca/html/1807/4350/displayprose274e.html |format=Online reprint |edition=online edition published by RPO Editors, Department of English, and University of Toronto Press as ''Samuel Johnson (1709-1784): Preface to his Edition of Shakespeare's Plays (1765)''. |others=Ian Lancashire (Ed.)|publisher=J. and R. Tonson and others |location=London |oclc=10834559}} ==External links== * {{gutenberg|no=1974|name=The Poetics of Aristotle'', translated by Samuel Henry Butcher}} * {{gutenberg|no=5429|name=Preface to Shakespeare'', by Samuel Johnson}} [[Category:Drama]] [[Category:Theatre]] [[Category:History of theatre]] [[Category:Ancient Greek theatre]] [[Category:Style (fiction)]]

'''Collier and Plucknett''' were a [[Warwick]], [[England]] based [[Victorian architecture|Victorian]]-era furniture maker, best known for their [[Gothic revival]] pieces.
James Plucknett formed a partnership with Frederick Collier in the 1860s, with a showroom in [[Leamington Spa]], and workshops in Warwick where [[Ambrose Heal]] was an apprentice.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationaltrustcollections.org.uk/object/10615.1|title=Cylinder bureau|publisher=[[National Trust]]|accessdate=3 April 2013}}</ref> The firm advertised themselves as:<ref name=Bonhams/> {{cquote|Collier and Plucknett: upholsterers, cabinet-makers and decorators by appointment to Her Majesty, and Manufacturers of rich carved furniture in the peculiar styles characteristic of the Gothic, Tudor and Elizabethan ages}} From adverts in trade directories the firm gained a wider reputation across the [[United Kingdom]], with national commissions supplementing work from local families. Their best known works were for [[William Gibbs (businessman)|William Gibbs]], who commissioned [[John Norton (architect)|John Norton]] to remodel his country house, [[Tyntesfield]]. [[William Cubitt|William Cubitt & Co.]] were the sub-contracted builders, whose formeman was George Plucknett, a relative of James Plucknett.<ref name=Bonhams/> Today, Tyntesfield is a [[National Trust]] property, and as well as items of furniture visitors can view the fully fitted Collier and Plucknett bathroom of Matilda Blanche Gibbs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntprints.com/image.php?imgref=127927|title=Matilda Blanche Gibb's new bathroom, refitted by the cabinetmakers Collier & Plucknett at Tyntesfield|publisher=[[National Trust]]|accessdate=3 April 2013}}</ref>
After Collier retired and the old firm was dissolved in January 1880,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://http |title=Dissolution of Collier and Plucknett Ltd |publisher=[[London Gazette]] |date=31 December 1880 |accessdate=3 April 2013 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160114075411/http://http// |archivedate=14 January 2016 |df= }}</ref> Plucknett went into partnership with James Steevens and they traded as Plucknett and Steevens. The partnership lasted six years and included the 1884 commission for the Town Hall in Leamington Spa. Plucknett traded independently from 1886 and in 1892 provided the furnishings for The Royal Pavilion at the Royal Agricultural Show.<ref name=Bonhams/>
The firm ceased trading in 1908 and the remaining stock was auctioned off.<ref name=Bonhams>{{cite web|url=http://www.bonhams.com/auctions/16879/lot/206/|title=Victorian carved oak Overmantel Mirror|publisher=[[Bonhams]]|date=18 Nov 2009|accessdate=3 April 2013}}</ref>
