revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2013}} {{primary sources|date=January 2009}} {{Infobox company |name = Landor Associates |logo = Landor Logo.svg |logo_size = 200px |type = [[Subsidiary]] |slogan = |foundation = 1941 |location= [[San Francisco]] |key_people = [[Walter Landor]] |industry = Branding |products = |revenue = |operating_income = |net_income = |num_employees = |parent = [[Young & Rubicam]] |owner = [[WPP plc]] |subsid = |homepage = {{url|https://landor.com}} }} '''Landor Associates''' is a brand consulting firm founded in 1941 by [[Walter Landor]], who pioneered some research, design, and consulting methods that the branding industry still uses.<ref name="WL bio">{{cite web|last=Gallagher|first=Bernard|title=Walter Landor, an industrial designer and pioneer in branding, created some of the world's most recognizable packages, brands, and trademarks|url=http://www.immigrantentrepreneurship.org/entry.php?rec=69|work=Immigrant Entrepreneurship|publisher=German Historical Institute|accessdate=25 October 2012}}</ref>
Headquartered in San Francisco, the company maintains 26 offices in 20 countries, including China, France, Germany, India, the United Kingdom, Mexico, Singapore, Australia, Japan, South Africa, and the United States.<ref>{{cite web|last=WPP|title=Landor Associates|url=http://www.wpp.com/wpp/companies/companydetail.htm?id=228|work=Our companies|publisher=WPP|accessdate=25 October 2012}}</ref> Landor is a member of the [[Young & Rubicam]] Group network within [[WPP plc]], the world's largest advertising company by revenues.<ref>{{cite web|last=WPP|title=Landor Associates|url=http://www.wpp.com/wpp/companies/companydetail.htm?id=228|work=Our companies|publisher=WPP|accessdate=25 October 2012}}</ref>
Landor's work includes brand research and valuation, brand strategy and architecture, brand purpose and green design, [[corporate identity]] and packaging design, innovation, naming and writing, branded experience{{clarify|date=February 2014}}, [[brand equity]] management, [[employee engagement]]{{clarify|date=February 2014}}, and digital branding.<ref>{{cite web|title=Landor Company Profile|url=http://www.wpp.com/wpp/companies/landor/|website=wpp.com|publisher=WPP|accessdate=17 January 2015}}</ref>
==History==
===Origin=== German immigrant Walter Landor and his wife Josephine (the original "associate") founded the company in 1941.<ref name=Ken>{{cite news|last=Kelly|first=Ken and Rick Clogher|title=The Ultimate Image Maker|newspaper=San Francisco Focus|date=August 1992}}</ref> Walter Landor intended to "...concentrate on designing everyday products that would make life more pleasant and more beautiful."<ref name=Ken />
Some of Landor's earliest designs were beer company logos that earned awards from the Brewers Association of America and the Small Brewers Association.<ref name=Pioneer>{{cite web|last=Gallagher|first=Bernie|title=Walter Landor: Portrait of a Pioneer|url=http://landor.com/#!/about/history/walter-landor|accessdate=25 October 2012}}</ref> For Arrowhead, Landor created a tilt bottle with two flat sides that could be poured without being lifted from the table.<ref name="WL bio" /> This unique design won several awards, drew media attention, and brought additional business to the firm.<ref>{{cite journal|title=So What's New about Water|journal=Good Packaging|date=n.d.|series=Landor Archive Project, Landor Design Collection, Archives Center, National Museum of American History}}</ref> It was also selected by the U.S. Department of Commerce to appear in three International Trade Fairs.<ref name="WL bio" />
Walter Landor favored what he felt was a client-driven approach. He was one of the first to apply consumer research to package design, and relied heavily on observing consumers in real-life situations—even soliciting in-store feedback from shoppers regarding label design.<ref name=Founder>{{cite web|last=Malherek|first=Joseph|title=Walter Landor: Graphic designer and founder of an influential corporate image consultancy|url=http://www.transatlanticperspectives.org/entry.php?rec=125|publisher=German Historical Institute|accessdate=25 October 2012}}</ref> In Walter Landor's philosophy, "The package itself must do the talking."<ref>{{cite news|last=Unknown|title=Packages Must Speak for Themselves|newspaper=San Francisco News-Call Bulletin|date=23 November 1956}}</ref>
As Landor's reputation grew, the company's client list expanded to encompass airlines, financial institutions, government agencies, hospitality services, and technology firms.<ref name="Founder"/> Over time, Landor broadened its consulting services to offer corporate and product naming, brand positioning and architecture, retail environment design, copywriting, internal brand engagement, digital branding, and BrandAsset Valuator analysis, corporate identity, and package design.<ref name="Pioneer"/>
===1960s-1980s=== [[File:The Klamath.TIF|thumb|From the 1960s to the 1980s, Landor Associates established headquarters on board a renovated ferryboat, Klamath, moored in San Francisco Bay.]] [[File:WalterLandor Klamath c1960s.jpg|thumb|Walter Landor working on the deck of the ''Klamath'' docked in San Francisco Bay (1960s)]] From the 1960s to the 1980s, Landor Associates established its headquarters on board the renovated ferryboat ''Klamath'', moored in San Francisco Bay.<ref>{{cite news|last=Gilpin|first=Kenneth N.|title=Walter Landor, 81, a Designer of Logos for Giant Corporations|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/13/obituaries/walter-landor-81-a-designer-of-logos-for-giant-corporations.html|accessdate=25 October 2012|newspaper=New York Times|date=13 June 2005}}</ref> This unusual arrangement was intended to foster creativity among the firm's employees.<ref>{{cite news|last=Fernandez|first=Elizabeth|title=Walter Landor, 81, designer: Driving force behind S.F.'s reputation in the applied arts|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/e/a/1995/06/11/METRO11293.dtl|accessdate=25 October 2012|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle|date=11 June 1995}}</ref> Mixing business with pleasure, the ''Klamath'' also hosted business symposia, cultural events and parties that included dignitaries, artists, business tycoons and celebrities.<ref name="WL bio" /> Although Landor's business eventually outgrew the ferryboat and moved to larger offices on land, the ''Klamath'' has remained its corporate symbol.<ref>{{cite web|last=Meyerowitz|first=Daniel|title=The Klamath: Landor's Icon of Innovation|url=http://www.landor.com/index.cfm?do=aboutus.klamath|accessdate=25 October 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110521133515/http://landor.com/index.cfm?do=aboutus.klamath|archivedate=21 May 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Recent years=== In 1989 the company was acquired by advertising agency [[Young & Rubicam]]<ref>{{cite news|last=Lazarus|first=George|title=Landor Associates acquired by Y&R|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1989-09-27/business/8901170468_1_landor-associates-barton-brands|accessdate=25 October 2012|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|date=27 September 1989}}</ref> and subsequently became part of [[WPP Group]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Unknown|title=WPP pays $4.7B for Y&R|url=http://money.cnn.com/2000/05/12/europe/wpp/|publisher=CNNMoney.com|accessdate=25 October 2012}}</ref>
In 1994, the Walter Landor/Landor Associates Collection was established at the National Museum of American History, part of the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, D.C.<ref>{{cite web|last=Unknown|title=Walter Landor Biography|url=http://www.aiga.org/content.cfm/medalist-walterlandor|publisher=AIGA|accessdate=25 October 2012}}</ref> The collection contains business records and personal papers belonging to Walter Landor, oral histories, and portfolio materials such as original designer notebooks.<ref>{{cite web|last=Unknown|title=Landor Design Collection|url=http://collections.si.edu/search/results.htm?q=Landor+archives&image.x=0&image.y=0|publisher=National Museum of American History|accessdate=25 October 2012}}</ref>
Since 2004, Landor has published an annual survey of brand strength measured over a three-year period.<ref>{{cite news|last=McGirt|first=Ellen|title=10 Breakaway Brands|url=http://money.cnn.com/magazines/fortune/fortune_archive/2006/09/18/8386123/index.htm|accessdate=25 October 2012|newspaper=Fortune|date=8 September 2006}}</ref> The Breakaway Brands list is based on data culled from the proprietary BrandAsset Valuator and is regularly cited in business publications including ''Fortune'' magazine and ''Forbes''.<ref>{{cite news|last=Roth|first=Hayes|title=Apple, Disney, Facebook: Breakaway Brands Offer Simple Pleasures|url=https://www.forbes.com/2010/10/08/google-facebook-disney-blackberry-apple-breakaway-brands-cmo-network.html|accessdate=25 October 2012|newspaper=Forbes.com|date=8 October 2010}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://landor.com/ Official '''Landor Associates''' website]
[[Category:Branding companies of the United States]] [[Category:Companies based in San Francisco]] [[Category:Design companies established in 1941]] [[Category:1941 establishments in California]] [[Category:American companies established in 1941]] [[Category:Branding companies]]

{{cleanup|reason=Article presumes a level of knowledge about the subject that the average reader does not have. The organization also needs work.|date=January 2015}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox writer | name = Laura Albert | image = Lauraalbert2.jpg | caption = Albert in her study | birth_name = Laura Victoria Albert | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1965|11|02}} | birth_place = [[New York City]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Author | genre = Fiction | pseudonym = {{flatlist| *[[JT LeRoy]] *Emily Frasier *Speedie *Laura Victoria *Gluttenberg}} | yearsactive = 1997–present | movement = | influences = | influenced = | website = }}
'''Laura Victoria Albert''' (born November 2, 1965) is an American author of writings that include works credited to the [[literary persona]] [[JT LeRoy]], whom Albert described as an "[[avatar]]",<ref>{{cite web|last=Albert|first=Laura|title=Laura Albert at The Moth "My Avatar & Me"|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oxAHHXE0HOw|publisher=YouTube|accessdate=2013-01-30}}</ref> saying she was able to write things as LeRoy that she could not have said as Laura Albert. Albert was born and raised in [[Brooklyn]]. She has also used the names Emily Frasier and Speedie, and published other works as Laura Victoria and Gluttenberg. Albert was sued for fraud when she signed a film option contract with her pseudonym; a jury found against her. The damages to be paid to the film company were settled out of court.
==Writing and other activities== During her youth, Albert was associated with [[punk rock]] and [[skinhead]] movements. She worked for several years as a [[phone sex]] operator, and reviewing sex sites and products on the Web. During the 1990s, she achieved some degree of fame as a freelance [[sexpert]], under the alias ''Laura Victoria''. At the same time, she started writing stories - using the pen name ''Terminator'' - in the voice of a young boy telling about his difficult childhood and life in the streets. ''Baby Doll'', JT LeRoy's first published story, appeared under the byline "Terminator" in a September 1997 anthology.<ref>[http://www.salon.com/2006/03/08/albert_3/ She is JT LeRoy], ''Salon.com'', 8 March 2006</ref>
Albert published three books under the JT LeRoy pseudonym – [[Sarah (LeRoy novel)|''Sarah'']]'' ''(2000),'' [[The Heart Is Deceitful Above All Things (novel)|The Heart Is Deceitful Above All Things]]'' (2001), and ''Harold's End'' (2004).
According to ''[[The New Republic]]'', ''Sarah'' was the second book Albert wrote but the first one published. The narrator is an adolescent among a group of [[lot lizard]]s, teen male prostitutes at truck stops. Each wears a signature raccoon penis bone necklace. The narrator aspires to be like his mother, Sarah, to move higher in the ranks of prostitutes. The book is by JT LeRoy but LeRoy's character is never directly named. The nom de lizard is 'Cherry Vanilla' or, more regularly he is called Sarah, after his mother. The writing is evocative of a folksy magical realism, vivid, colorful phrases to describe the unconventional and gritty reality of a young boy.<ref>{{cite web|last=Osgood |first=Kelsey |url=https://newrepublic.com/article/136715/jt-leroys-fiction-good |title=Is JT Leroy's Fiction Any Good? |publisher=New Republic |date=2016-09-12 |accessdate=2017-03-05}}</ref>
SF Weekly's literary critic described ''The Heart Is Deceitful Above All Things'' as "essentially the prequel to ''Sarah''." This novel is a collection of ten stories that describe a "chaotic, nomadic, and abuse-filled childhood." In the opening story, "Disappearances," a young boy named Jeremiah leaves a stable foster home to reunite with his biological mother, Sarah, an 18-year-old drug addict. The stories begin in Appalachia and follow the characters to California. Jeremiah's grandfather beats him while invoking judgmental Christian dogma. The abuse is the most consistent form of physical touch Jeremiah knows, and he comes to interpret it as a form of love.<ref>{{cite web|last=Bachtold |first=Beth |url=http://archives.sfweekly.com/sanfrancisco/the-heart-is-deceitful-above-all-things/Content?oid=2142804 |title=The Heart Is Deceitful Above All Things | Books | San Francisco | San Francisco News and Events | SF Weekly |website=Archives.sfweekly.com |date=2001-08-29 |accessdate=2017-03-05}}</ref>
Albert wrote "Dreams of Levitation," Sharif Hamza's short film for [[NOWNESS]], and has also written for the acclaimed television series ''[[Deadwood (TV series)|Deadwood]]''. The film "Radiance," which she also wrote, was made an Official Selection of the 2015 Bokeh South African International Fashion Film Festival. She collaborated with director and playwright [[Robert Wilson (director)|Robert Wilson]] for the international exhibition of his VOOM video portraits, and with the catalog for his "Frontiers: Visions of the Frontier" at [[Institut Valencià d'Art Modern]] (IVAM).<ref>{{cite web|author=JT LEROY Writer, 2006 Music by Lou Reed |url=http://www.dissidentusa.com/robert-wilson/subjects/jt-leroy/ |title=Jt Leroy |publisher=Dissident USA |date= |accessdate=2017-03-05}}</ref> In 2012 she served on the juries of the first Brasilia International Film Festival and the Sapporo International Short Film Festival; she also attended Brazil's international book fair, Bienal Brasil do Livro e da Leitura, where she and [[Alice Walker]] were the U.S. representatives. Brazil's Geração Editorial has re-released the JT LeRoy books in a boxset under Laura Albert's name, and she and JT are the subjects of the hit Brazilian rock musical JT, Um Conto de Fadas Punk ("JT, A Punk Fairy Tale"). On March 11, 2014, the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' reported<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/garchik/article/Long-lost-Ukrainian-uncle-has-left-you-5-million-5304867.php|title=Long-lost Ukrainian uncle has left you $5 million|publisher=|accessdate=August 22, 2016}}</ref> that the Academy of Friends Oscar Party in San Francisco invited JT LeRoy – played by gender-fluid fashion model Rain Dove Dubilewski – to walk the runway<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jGd-Czhqk6I|title=JT LeRoy Lives at lauraalbert.org|first=|last=Jasmin Lim|date=March 11, 2014|publisher=|accessdate=August 22, 2016|via=YouTube}}</ref> as part of its HIV/AIDS fundraiser.
In 2016, Laura Albert starred in a documentary about JT LeRoy that premiered at Sundance, titled ''Author: The JT LeRoy Story'' directed by [[Jeff Feuerzeig]].
Albert has taught at [[Dave Eggers]]' [[826 Valencia]] and the [[California College of the Arts]] in San Francisco, and has lectured with artist Jasmin Lim at [[Artists' Television Access]] with SF Camerawork's Chuck Mobley, in conjunction with a window [[Installation art|installation]] about her work. A spokeswoman for the successful "Heart for Eye" campaign to raise funds for [[restorative eye surgery|eye surgery]] for children, Albert hosted a television segment and was both an interviewee and an interviewer of inspirational women such as Anastasia Barbieri and [[Anh Duong]]. She was photographed by [[Steven Klein (photographer)|Steven Klein]] for ''QVEST'' magazine and by Kai Regan for his "Reckless Endangerment" at ALIFE; she has also done fashion shoots for [[Christian Lacroix]] and [[John Galliano]]. Albert profiled [[Juergen Teller]] for the 2003 Citibank Photography Prize catalogue; and published her reminiscence of [[Lou Reed]] in [[The Forward]]. She was a catalog contributor for the "Blind Cut" exhibition at New York's [[Marlborough Chelsea]] and collaborated with Williamsburg band [[Japanther]], releasing a limited-edition cassette under the name ''True Love in a Large Room'', with original artwork by [[Winston Smith]]. She has also written for dot429, the world's largest LGBTA professional network, and been an invited speaker at their annual conferences in New York.
==Pseudonym== As a teen, Albert called suicide hotlines for help. She felt more comfortable speaking with strangers as a boy because of the sexual abuse and degradation she'd suffered that seemed, in her world, relatively common as a female. She found counselors to be sympathetic when she called as a male.{{Citation needed|date=June 2017}} Calling a suicide hotline in the 1990s, she reached Terrence Owens, a psychologist with the McAuley Adolescent Psychiatric Program at [[St. Mary's Medical Center (San Francisco)|St. Mary's Medical Center]] in San Francisco. Owens did not know her as Laura Albert at the time, but as Terminator. She explored this role in their conversations. Owens is credited with encouraging Terminator, who later became known as JT LeRoy, to write during their phone therapy sessions.<ref name="sfgate1">{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/article/Soul-baring-fiction-author-J-T-LeRoy-plays-with-2556606.php |title=Soul-baring fiction author J.T. LeRoy plays with gender - and identity. Does it really matter who he is? |publisher=[[San Francisco Chronicle|SFGate]] |date=2005-12-17 |accessdate=2017-03-05}}</ref>{{Failed verification|date=June 2017}} Laura Albert explained the circumstances of JT's existence in a Fall 2006 ''[[Paris Review]]'' interview with Nathaniel Rich.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theparisreview.org/miscellaneous/5664/being-jt-leroy-nathaniel-rich|title=Being JT LeRoy|first=Nathaniel|last=Rich|date=|work=theparisreview.org|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref> She attested that she could not have written from raw emotion without the right to be presented to the world via JT LeRoy, whom she calls her "phantom limb." "I had survived sexual and physical abuse and found a way to turn it into art," she later wrote in [[The Forward]]. "Having struggled with issues of gender fluidity when there was no language for it, I created a character both on and off the page who modeled this as yet to be named state of being."<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://forward.com/culture/351569/how-to-kill-a-butterfly-like-elena-ferrante-or-jt-leroy/?attribution=home-hero-item-text-4 |title=How To Kill a Butterfly Like Elena Ferrante or JT Leroy - Culture – |website=Forward.com |date=2016-10-10 |accessdate=2017-03-05}}</ref>
Albert went on to pursue literary conversations under the guise of JT Leroy, or as his friend Speedie. According to author Mary Gaitskill, at a dinner date in which she and LeRoy were to meet, instead, JT's friend, Speedie, sat down, and she and Gaitskill had a long conversation. "She struck me as very bright and very young," recalled Gaitskill.<ref name="newyorkmetro1"/>
Some accused Albert of intentionally manipulating people with a sympathetic persona such as LeRoy's in order to gain access and publication that she would not otherwise have been able to achieve as Laura Albert. According to the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'', "Whether the hoax was a performance-art lark or a cynical Ponzi scheme has been hotly debated. Those who defend the work argue that the stories -- no matter the source -- have touched people, furnishing their minds as literature does. And, they note, the books have always been labeled fiction." <ref name="sfgate1"/> Said Gaitskill in one interview, "It's occurred to me that the whole thing with Jeremy is a hoax, but I felt that even if it turned out to be a hoax, it's a very enjoyable one. And a hoax that exposes things about people, the confusion between love and art and publicity. A hoax that would be delightful and if people are made fools of, it would be okay—in fact, it would be useful."<ref name="newyorkmetro1"/> What is not debated is that there was a demand for JT LeRoy to appear in public. ''San Francisco Chronicle'' commented that, "The permeable membrane between author and subject was tantalizing."<ref name="sfgate1"/> LeRoy was known to avoid the spotlight and refused to be labelled permanently male or female. His edgy work, as well as his elusiveness, drew attention from the media and developed a cult-like following, with praise from celebrities including [[Winona Ryder]], [[Courtney Love]], and [[Bono]].{{Citation needed|date=June 2017}} The publisher and marketers capitalized on this fascination to provide further opportunities to expose the books. ''The Heart is Deceitful Above All Things'' was described in the Publisher's Comments as "The extraordinary stories that brought the author a cult following at the age of sixteen," and "loosely edited autobiographical stories" for the persona of JT LeRoy.
Instead of discarding her pseudonym and exposing herself in order to remind the public that LeRoy's story, though published as fiction, was not in fact, a memoir, Laura Albert chose her sister-in-law, Savannah Knoop, a 25-year-old aspiring clothes designer, to embody the pseudonym in public. In 2001, a person claiming to be LeRoy began appearing in public, usually decked out in wigs and sunglasses".<ref name="newyorkmetro1"/> Thereafter, the persona of JT LeRoy took on a public life of its own with a backstory that echoed the settings and events described in the books. Savannah Knoop as JT LeRoy, wore wigs and sunglasses, and was often accompanied by Laura Albert as her roommate, called Speedie/Emily Frasier, and Geoffrey Knoop, called Astor.{{Citation needed|date=June 2017}}
A friend, Steve O'Connor, said that he knew Laura Albert had written the books. Star photographer [[Mary Ellen Mark]] claimed that when she photographed Savannah Knoop for a ''Vanity Fair'' shoot she was certain that Savannah Knoop was a woman and recalled the costumed JT LeRoy persona as "a masquerade that a lot of fancy people fell for...A put-on that didn't harm anybody." <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/living/article/IDENTITY-CRISIS-How-former-sex-writer-Laura-2501521.php |title=IDENTITY CRISIS / How former sex writer Laura Albert and her extended family became 'JT LeRoy,' pulling off one of the strangest literary hoaxes of our time |publisher=[[SFGate]] |date=2006-03-19 |accessdate=2017-03-05}}</ref>
However, [[Stephen Beachy]] published an article in 2005 to imply that Laura Albert wrote the stories,<ref name="newyorkmetro1"/> and later the ''[[New York Times]]'' confirmed that JT LeRoy was the invention of Speedie/Emily, whose real name is Laura Albert. ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'' also publicly announced that Laura Albert wrote all of J.T.'s books, articles, and stories, corresponded as J.T. by e-mail, and spoke as him on the phone.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/style/2006/04/jtleroy200604|title=The Boy Who Cried Author|publisher=''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]''|date= |accessdate=2017-03-05}}</ref> Savannah Knoop stopped making public appearances as JT LeRoy. The media's attention shifted from a fascination with the persona of JT LeRoy and the writing, to a castigation of Laura Albert. Laura Albert did not publish writing as JT LeRoy again.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3756484/|title=The Cult of JT LeRoy|author=|date=November 14, 2014|publisher=|accessdate=April 22, 2017|via=IMDb}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.sfgate.com/culture/2006/01/09/revealed-jt-leroy-is-merely-a-figment-of-your-imagination/|title=Revealed! JT LeRoy Is Merely A Figment Of Your Imagination|author=|date=January 10, 2006|work=sfgate.com|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.sfgate.com/culture/2006/02/06/the-latest-on-leroygate-whoever-he-is-jt-has-boobs/|title=The Latest on LeRoygate: Whoever He Is, JT Has Boobs|author=|date=February 7, 2006|work=sfgate.com|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://events.sfgate.com/event/author-the-jt-leroy-storyoctober-14-201657fee610607ff|title=Author The JT LeRoy Story|author=|date=|work=sfgate.com|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/books/article/Memoir-review-The-Real-JT-LeRoy-s-story-3191469.php|title=Memoir review: The 'Real' JT LeRoy's story|author=|date=|work=sfgate.com|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/article/Catching-up-with-hellip-Laura-Albert-3248047.php|title=Catching up with {hellip} Laura Albert|author=|date=|work=sfgate.com|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/article/Soul-baring-fiction-author-J-T-LeRoy-plays-with-2556606.php|title=Soul-baring fiction author J.T. LeRoy plays with gender -- and identity. Does it really matter who he is?|author=|date=|work=sfgate.com|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/living/article/IDENTITY-CRISIS-How-former-sex-writer-Laura-2501521.php|title=IDENTITY CRISIS / How former sex writer Laura Albert and her extended family became 'JT LeRoy,' pulling off one of the strangest literary hoaxes of our time|author=|date=|work=sfgate.com|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/movies/article/Documentary-captures-the-JT-LeRoy-literary-9195303.php|title=Documentary captures the JT LeRoy literary deception|author=|date=|work=sfgate.com|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/movies/article/Film-noir-set-in-Mission-headlines-SF-IndieFest-6047047.php|title=Film noir set in Mission headlines SF IndieFest|author=|date=|work=sfgate.com|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/movies/industrybuzz/article/Industry-Buzz-Strange-tale-of-JT-Leroy-told-in-6117070.php|title=Industry Buzz: Strange tale of JT Leroy told in film|author=|date=|work=sfgate.com|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/news/article/Man-who-helped-create-JT-Leroy-unmasks-scheme-2505029.php|title=Man who helped create JT Leroy unmasks scheme / Female partner got artistic boost after they forged persona|author=|date=|work=sfgate.com|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/news/article/New-clues-in-mystery-story-of-elusive-S-F-author-2543920.php|title=New clues in mystery story of elusive S.F. author JT LeRoy|author=|date=|work=sfgate.com|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/style/article/SFStyle-Writer-Laura-Albert-an-indie-fashion-5549284.php|title=SFStyle: Writer Laura Albert an indie fashion fighter|author=|date=|work=sfgate.com|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/thingstodo/article/Out-loud-Stephen-Beachy-2524119.php|title=Out loud: Stephen Beachy|author=|date=|work=sfgate.com|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/garchik/article/LEAH-GARCHIK-2506533.php|title=LEAH GARCHIK|author=|date=|work=sfgate.com|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/garchik/article/LEAH-GARCHIK-2513454.php|title=LEAH GARCHIK|author=|date=|work=sfgate.com|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/garchik/article/LEAH-GARCHIK-2517098.php|title=LEAH GARCHIK|author=|date=|work=sfgate.com|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/garchik/article/LEAH-GARCHIK-2536524.php|title=LEAH GARCHIK|author=|date=|work=sfgate.com|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/living/article/BACK-IN-FASHION-Savannah-Knoop-has-survived-the-2466229.php|title=BACK IN FASHION / Savannah Knoop has survived the JT Leroy scandal and is trying her hand at a new career|author=|date=|work=sfgate.com|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref>
Over the next decade, without the pseudonym, Albert gradually became more publicly expressive. Writing for ''The New York Times'' in 2016, Albert noted, "I meet a lot of young people and they're shocked that it was an issue to even have an avatar. Because they've grown up where you have multiple fully formed avatars."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/01/t-magazine/entertainment/author-jt-leroy-story-documentary-laura-albert.html|title=Ten Years Later, the 'Real' JT LeRoy Tells All|date=August 1, 2016|work=The New York Times|accessdate=August 22, 2016}}</ref>
Media discussion about Albert's creation of the JT LeRoy pseudonym and public persona continues to this day. "Looking back, Laura Albert anticipated just about all of it," commented author Adam Langer. "Long before we had split our personas into the lives we truly live and the ones that we choose to create on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, and everywhere else, Albert created her own avatar." <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.interviewmagazine.com/culture/laura-albert/ |title=Laura Albert - Page |publisher=Interview Magazine |date=2015-11-19 |accessdate=2017-03-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oxAHHXE0HOw|title=Laura Albert at The Moth "My Avatar & Me"|first=|last=Jasmin Lim|date=November 24, 2010|publisher=|accessdate=April 22, 2017|via=YouTube}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jGd-Czhqk6I|title=JT LeRoy Lives at lauraalbert.org|first=|last=Jasmin Lim|date=March 11, 2014|publisher=|accessdate=April 22, 2017|via=YouTube}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/12/movies/asia-argento-and-others-are-angry-about-being-in-jt-leroy-documentary.html|title=Asia Argento and Others Are Angry About Being in JT LeRoy Documentary|first=Colin|last=Moynihan|date=September 11, 2016|publisher=|accessdate=April 22, 2017|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://newrepublic.com/article/136715/jt-leroys-fiction-good|title=Is JT Leroy's Fiction Any Good?|author=|date=September 12, 2016|work=newrepublic.com|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://decider.com/2017/02/17/author-jt-leroy-story-review-amazon-prime/|title='Author: The JT Leroy Story' Turns The Page On The Greatest Literary Hoax Of The 21st Century|author=|date=February 17, 2017|work=decider.com|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref>
==Film option and lawsuit== [[Antidote International Films, Inc.]] and its president [[Jeff Levy-Hinte|Jeffrey Levy-Hinte]] announced plans for a film adaptation of ''Sarah'' to be directed by [[Steven Shainberg]].<ref name="NYT Writer's Trial">Feuer, Alan. "[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9900EFDF113FF931A15755C0A9619C8B63 In Writer's Trial, a Conflict Over Roles of Art and Money]". (June 22, 2007) ''[[The New York Times]]''. Retrieved 2013-09-10.</ref> Albert signed a contract giving Antidote an option for the film rights to ''Sarah'' in the name of JT LeRoy.<ref name="NYT Jury Fraud">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/06/23/nyregion/23writer.html |title=Jury Finds JT LeRoy Was Fraud |first=Alan |last=Feuer |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=June 23, 2007}}</ref> When Antidote discovered that JT LeRoy was a pseudonym of Albert, it sued Albert for fraud, alleging that the option contract was void. A jury found against Albert and ordered her to pay Antidote the $110,000 she had received for the contract, as well as $6,500 in punitive damages.<ref>Westfeldt, Amy. "[http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/movies/2007-06-23-4245882828_x.htm Jury: novel bought by company fraudulent]." U.S.A. Today. Retrieved 2013-09-18.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://archives.sfweekly.com/thesnitch/2007/08/01/how-much-does-it-cost-to-be-jt-leroy|title=How Much Does It Cost To Be JT LeRoy?|first=Martin|last=Kuz|date=|work=sfweekly.com|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref> Albert was also ordered to pay $350,000 in legal fees to Antidote.<ref>Feuer, Alan. "[https://www.nytimes.com/2007/08/01/nyregion/01leroy.html?_r=0 Judge Orders Author to Pay Film Company $350,000 in Legal Fees]". (August 1, 1007) ''[[The New York Times]]''. Retrieved 2013-9-10.</ref> Albert reached an out-of-court settlement with Antidote that allowed her to retain the copyright for her past and future works and gave Antidote payments based on Albert's future earnings.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.adweek.com/galleycat/laura-albert-settles-film-companys-fraud-suit/11030?red=as |title=Laura Albert settles film company's "fraud" suit |publisher=AdWeek |date=September 14, 2009}}</ref><ref name="newyorkmetro1">{{cite web|url=http://nymag.com/nymetro/news/people/features/14718/|title=Who is the Real JT LeRoy?|author=|date=|work=nymag.com|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}<!-- https://web.archive.org/web/20051024022508/http://newyorkmetro.com/nymetro/news/people/features/14718/index4.html --></ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/culture/film/laura-albert-tells-the-stranger-than-fiction-story-of-jt-leroy-1.2729936|title=Laura Albert tells the stranger-than-fiction story of JT LeRoy|author=|date=|work=irishtimes.com|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt5278462/|title=Author: The JT LeRoy Story|author=|date=July 29, 2016|publisher=|accessdate=April 22, 2017|via=IMDb}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b08cgm58|title=The Great Literary Scandal: The JT Leroy Story, Storyville - BBC Four|author=|date=|work=bbc.co.uk|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://archives.sfweekly.com/sanfrancisco/living-without-leroy/Content?oid=2169973|title=Living Without LeRoy|first=Jonathan|last=Kiefer|date=|work=sfweekly.com|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfweekly.com/news/alberts-end/|title=Albert's End - By - SF Weekly|author=|date=August 1, 2007|work=sfweekly.com|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://archives.sfweekly.com/sanfrancisco/the-cult-of-jt-leroy-film-review/Content?oid=3467891|title="The Cult of JT LeRoy": How Much About JT LeRoy is Too Much About JT LeRoy?|first=Jonathan|last=Kiefer|date=|work=sfweekly.com|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfweekly.com/film/the-cult-of-jt-leroy-how-much-about-jt-leroy-is-too-much-about-jt-leroy/|title="The Cult of JT LeRoy": How Much About JT LeRoy is Too Much About JT LeRoy? - By - SF Weekly|author=|date=March 11, 2015|work=sfweekly.com|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{External links|date=October 2016}} *[http://lauraalbert.org Official website] * {{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V1Pd2m7qjSM|title=Asia Argento & Laura Albert Skype Interview|first=|last=lauratrucks|date=July 5, 2013|publisher=|accessdate=April 22, 2017|via=YouTube}} * {{cite web|url=http://jasminlim.com/Nicole-Gagne-on-JT-LeRoy-hoax-Laura-Albert-and-Oscar-Wilde.html|title=The Importance of Being JT LeRoy|author=|date=|work=jasminlim.com|accessdate=April 22, 2017}} * [http://forward.com/articles/186348/what-i-learned-from-lou-reed/#ixzz2j2P5sf00 What I Learned From Lou Reed] * {{cite web|url=http://matt-runkle.blogspot.com/2011/10/personic-truth-interview-with-jasmin.html|title=Matt Runkle: Personic Truth: An Interview with Jasmin Lim|first=Matt|last=Runkle|date=October 20, 2011|work=matt-runkle.blogspot.com|accessdate=April 22, 2017}} * {{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/09/25/travel/tmagazine/25DISNEY.html|title=Uncle Walt, Parlez-Vous Français?|first=JT|last=Leroy|date=September 25, 2005|publisher=|accessdate=April 22, 2017|via=NYTimes.com}} * {{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/01/09/books/08cnd-book.html|title=The Unmasking of JT Leroy: In Public, He's a She|first=Warren St|last=John|date=January 9, 2006|publisher=|accessdate=April 22, 2017|via=NYTimes.com}} * {{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/02/07/books/07lero.html|title=Figure in JT Leroy Case Says Partner Is Culprit|first=Warren St|last=John|date=February 7, 2006|publisher=|accessdate=April 22, 2017|via=NYTimes.com}} *[http://www.salon.com/news/feature/2006/03/08/albert/ She is JT LeRoy] * {{cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/2000/10/19/albert/|title=Steal this millennium!|first=R. U.|last=Sirius|date=|work=salon.com|accessdate=April 22, 2017}} *[http://www.theparisreview.org/viewmedia.php/prmMID/5664 Being JT LeRoy] * {{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/06/20/nyregion/20cnd-writer.html|title=Writer Testifies About Source of Nom de Plume|first=Alan|last=Feuer|date=June 20, 2007|publisher=|accessdate=April 22, 2017|via=NYTimes.com}} * {{cite web|url=http://www.wtfpod.com/podcast/episode-738-laura-albert-jeff-feuerzeig|title=Episode 738 - Laura Albert & Jeff Feuerzeig|author=[[Marc Maron]]|date=1 September 2016|work=wtfpod.com|accessdate=April 22, 2017}} * {{cite web|url=http://globalcomment.com/binding-truth-revisiting-antidote-films-vs-laura-albert-aka-jt-leroy/|title=Will the real JT LeRoy please stand up|author=|date=|work=globalcomment.com|accessdate=April 22, 2017}} * {{cite web|url= http://www.laweekly.com/arts/the-lies-and-follies-of-laura-albert-aka-jt-leroy-2152091|title=No Exit Plan: The Lies and Follies of Laura Albert, aka, JT Leroy|first=Nancy|last=Rommelmann|date=February 20, 2008|publisher=|accessdate=January 5, 2018|via=LAWeekly.com}}

revision.text:
[[File:Castillo pirotécnico (fuegos artificiales).ogv|thumb|A "castillo" or castle fireworks frame set off in Mexico City]] '''Mexican handcrafted fireworks''' production is mostly concentrated in the [[State of Mexico]] in central [[Mexico]]. The self-declared fireworks capital of Mexico is [[Tultepec]], just north of [[Mexico City]]. Although the main ingredient for fireworks, gunpowder, was brought by the [[conquistador]]s in the 16th century, fireworks became popular in Mexico in the 19th century. Today, it is Latin America’s second largest producer, almost entirely for domestic use, with products ranging from small firecrackers to large shells and frames for pyrotechnics called “castillos” (castles) and “toritos” (little bulls). The industry is artisanal, with production concentrated in family-owned workshops and small factories with a number operating illegally. The relatively informal production and sales of fireworks have made it dangerous with a number of notable accidents in from the late 1990s to the present, despite attempts to safety regulations.
==History== [[File:BullFrameMAPDF.JPG|thumb|A "torito" or bull frame for fireworks on display at the [[Museo de Arte Popular]] in Mexico City]] Although pre Hispanic cultures had ways of manipulating fire for ceremonial purposes, the popularity of fireworks came to Mexico late, in the 19th century.<ref name="popularte">{{cite web |url=http://www.uv.mx/popularte/esp/scriptphp.php?sid=399 |title=Juegos Pirotécnicos, cohetes y pólvora |publisher=Universidad Veracruzana |location=Veracruz |language=Spanish |trans-title=Pyrotechnic sets, rockets and powder |accessdate=June 8, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071016064326/http://www.uv.mx/popularte/esp/scriptphp.php?sid=399 |archivedate=October 16, 2007 |df= }}</ref><ref name="elgrito">{{cite news |title= REPORTAJE /EL GRITO ENTRE FUEGOS |url= http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2003/09/15/02an1cul.php?origen=cultura.php&fly=1 |newspaper= La Jornada |location=Mexico City |date=September 15, 2003 |accessdate=June 8, 2012 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Special report/The cry among fireworks }}</ref> Fireworks were invented by the Chinese, and for ceremonial and religious use, which is their main use today in Mexico.<ref name="lasredes">{{cite news |title=Los fuegos artificiales |author=Conti González Báez |url=http://radioredam.mx/grc/redam.nsf/vwALL/XPAO-6RSLZV |newspaper=Radio Red AM |location=Mexico City |date=July 15, 2006 |accessdate=June 8, 2012 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Fireworks |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130221035330/http://radioredam.mx/grc/redam.nsf/vwALL/XPAO-6RSLZV |archivedate=February 21, 2013 |df= }}</ref>
Fireworks production and use came to Mexico through Europe. The main ingredient for them, gunpowder, came with the conquistadors but for military purposes. The first place to start gunpowder manufacture was Tultepec, which during the colonial period was separate from Mexico City and had an abundance of saltpeter, from which the chemicals could be extracted.<ref name="sustento">{{cite news |title=Pirotecnia: El sustento de un pueblo |author=Alicia Rivera |url=http://www.milenio.com/cdb/doc/impreso/9024568 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130128171900/http://www.milenio.com/cdb/doc/impreso/9024568 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=January 28, 2013 |newspaper=Milenio Edomex |location=Toluca |date=September 12, 2011 |accessdate=June 8, 2012 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Pyrotechics: The sustenance of a town }}</ref> The popularity of fireworks begin in the 19th century, after Mexico’s independence.<ref name="elgrito"/><ref name="sustento"/> Fireworks production, sale and handling is covered by the federal Armas, Municiones, Explosivas y Pirotecnia law, with the aim of reducing the risk associated with the product.<ref name="lasredes"/> This law was enacted in 1963, more geared towards the military. Recent efforts to update the law have included providing training and other measures to extend legal status to irregular manufacturers.<ref name="elgrito"/> Fireworks are a main staple of Mexican religious festivals, especially those for patron saints. However, the main occasion for fireworks use are the celebrations surrounding Mexican Independence, which begins with the reenactment of [[Father Hidalgo]]’s cry against the Spanish at 11pm on September 15, 1810. The fireworks are ignited just after the reenactment.<ref name="elgrito"/>
==Manufacture== [[File:FireworksCastleMAPDF.JPG|thumb|A castle frame for fireworks on display at the Museo de Arte Popular in Mexico City]] [[File:FeriaPirtecniaTultepec41.JPG|thumb|left|Portions of a "castillo" or castle fireworks frame set off at the National Fireworks Fair in Tultepec]] In Latin America, Mexico is the second largest producer of fireworks, after [[Brazil]].<ref name="elgrito"/> There are over 50,000 families in Mexico which manufacture fireworks, many illegally,<ref name="elgrito"/><ref name="lasredes"/> with 40,000 families in sixty municipalities in the State of Mexico alone.<ref name="arriesgan">{{cite news |title=Artesanos pirotécnicos arriesgan la vida |author=Kristian Villaseñor |url=http://www.hoyestado.com/nota.php?id=1635 |newspaper=Hoy Estado de Mexico |location=Toluca |date=February 8, 2012 |accessdate=June 8, 2012 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Pyrotechnic artisans risk their lives |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130125165948/http://www.hoyestado.com/nota.php?id=1635 |archivedate=January 25, 2013 |df= }}</ref> Many of these artisans are located in the municipalities of [[Almoloya de Juárez]], [[Axapusco]], [[Tianguistenco]], [[Tenancingo, State of Mexico|Tenancingo]], [[Tenango del Valle]], [[Otumba, State of Mexico|Otumba]], [[Capulhuac]], [[Coyotepec]], [[Tecámac]] and [[Texcoco, State of Mexico|Texcoco]], along with the community of San Mateo Otzacatipan.<ref name="sustento"/><ref name="ramas">{{cite web |url= http://portal2.edomex.gob.mx/edomex/estado/identidadmexiquense/artesanias/ramasartesanales/EDOMEX_025671 |title= Pirotecnia |publisher=State of Mexico |location=Mexico |language=Spanish |trans-title=Pyrotechnics |accessdate=June 8, 2012 }}</ref> However, the biggest producer is the municipality of Tultepec, located just north of Mexico City, which accounts for 25% of all the fireworks produced in Mexico.<ref name="elgrito"/>
There are three internationally recognized pyrotechnic enterprises in Mexico. Lux Pirotecnia is located in [[Zumpango, State of Mexico|Zumpango]], known for its rigorous manufacturing methods and participation in international competitions in Europe and Canada.<ref name="elgrito"/> Pirotecnia Reyes won first place at the International Fireworks Competition in [[Hannover]], Germany in 2011 with a fireworks and music show lasting 25 minutes. This enterprise was founded by Manues Reyes Arias who received the 1996 [[Premio Nacional de las Artes]] .<ref name="concurso">{{cite news |title= Artesanos de Tultepec ganan concurso de pirotecnia en Alemania |url= http://mx.noticias.yahoo.com/artesanos-tultepec-ganan-concurso-pirotecnia-alemania-214200963.html |newspaper= El Universal /Yahoo noticias |location=Mexico |date=September 28, 2011 |accessdate=June 8, 2012 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Artisans of Tultepec win pyrotechnics competition in Germany }}</ref>
Most artisans are trained by their elders with no formal training or formal degrees in chemistry or engineering, although some have abroad for training as well to promote products.<ref name="arriesgan"/><ref name="preservar">{{cite news |title= Tultepec: artesanos de la pirotecnia buscan preservar una tradición de casi 200 años |author= Silvia Chávez González |url= http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2008/09/15/index.php?section=estados&article=035n1est |newspaper=La Jornada |location=Mexico City |date=September 15, 2008 |accessdate=June 8, 2012 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Tultepec: Pyrotechnic artisans look to preserve an almost 200-year-old tradition }}</ref> Artisans buy ingredients in local chemical supply shops and local markets, which are then mixed by hand in family owned workshops and small factories. Everything is made from scratch, with cartridges made of packing tape and scrap paper purchased in bulk. Often, the fireworks are packaged in nothing but old cornmeal and dog food bags.<ref name="usatoday">{{cite news |title= Mexican fireworks pack too much pow |author=Chris Hawley |url= https://www.usatoday.com/news/world/2009-07-01-mexicofireworks_N.htm |newspaper= USA TODAY |date=July 1, 2009 |accessdate=June 8, 2012}}</ref> Most artisans are not formal employees, but rather work in the family business. The formulas used by each workshop are individual and guarded by the families that own them.<ref name="preservar"/> Workshops are ranked with the best artisans receiving the “maestro” (master) title, able to produce elaborate products such as castillos, bombas, toritos and synchronized fireworks/light/music shows.<ref name="preservar"/>
Mexican firework production include a number of explosive objects such as “rocas” (rocks, a kind of powerful firecracker), “vampiros” (vampires), “patas de mula” (mule hooves) and “bombas” (large rockets) as well as frames with pyrotechnics called “castillos” (castles), “toritos” (little bulls), “canastillas” (little baskets) and [[Burning of Judas|Judas figures]] .<ref name="ramas"/><ref name="usatoday"/> Castillos are generally large wooden frames covered with brilliant flares, which can cost between 20,000 to 250,000 pesos depending on size and complexity.<ref name="preservar"/><ref name="usatoday"/> These are most often made to honor patron saints or Mexico’s patriot heroes.<ref name="preservar"/> Toritos are smaller frames in the shape of a bull, designed to be worn or carried by a person as they are lit, chasing passers-by in the street during festivals.<ref name="elgrito"/> A version of the torito is designed to released candy when set off, which as the effect of having children run toward it, instead of running away. Toritos run about 800 pesos in the market.<ref name="preservar"/>
The most elaborate product is called a “piromusical” (pyro-musical) a set of fireworks synchronized to music and sometimes lights, with an average commercial price of about 10,000 pesos a minute, usually lasting about fourteen minutes.<ref name="preservar"/>
==Tultepec== [[File:FireworksVirginDoc2.JPG|thumb|Setting off cohetones or rockets during a religious festival in [[Colonia Doctores]] in Mexico City]] Most fireworks in Mexico are produced in the State of Mexico, especially the municipality of Tultepec just north of Mexico City, which has declared itself to be the “pyrotechnics capital of Mexico.”<ref name="usatoday"/><ref name="recorre">{{cite news |title= México recorre su Historia con fuegos artificiales a un paso del Bicentenario |url= http://www.elperiodicodemexico.com/nota.php?id=292936&sec=Nacional-Poblacion |newspaper=El Periodico de Mexico |location=Mexico City |date=September 18, 2009 |accessdate=June 8, 2012 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Mexico revisits its history with fireworks during its Bicentennial }}</ref> This area has a two-hundred year tradition of making fireworks, with, about 65 percent of the population of the municipality is involved directly or indirectly in fireworks production.<ref name="sustento"/><ref name="preservar"/> In Tultepec, all fireworks are made by hand, including decoration and wrapping, mostly in small factories or workshops that produce everything from small firecrackers to twelve-inch shells for professional shows.<ref name="sustento"/><ref name="usatoday"/> Tultepec is also one of the main suppliers of ingredients needed to make fireworks.<ref name="ramas"/>
Most fireworks production in the municipality is crowded into an area called the La Saucera pyrotechnic zone, located outside the town of Tultepec near the communities of Xahuento and Lomas.<ref name="arriesgan"/><ref name="preservar"/> Originally, all of the fireworks production was scattered around the municipality, but after the [[Mexico City fireworks disaster|explosion and fire]] of fireworks stands at the [[La Merced Market, Mexico City|La Merced Market in Mexico City]] in 1988, authorities decided to force artisans into one area away from residential areas and with security precautions such as special warehouses for finished products and to store chemicals.<ref name="preservar"/>
The State of Mexico’s largest fireworks market is located here as well, called the Mercado de San Pablito, constructed by the state which spent nine million pesos to construct 300 study block stalls.<ref name="concurso"/><ref name="preservar"/> However, this market suffered major explosions in 2005 and 2006, reducing most of the stalls to rubble on both occasions. The market also has problems with regulations on how much they can store and sell in the market, as well as the harassment of customers leaving the market by police.<ref name="preservar"/> This has led to a fifty percent reduction in sales volume, with sales shifting to other, often clandestine, outlets in the municipality.<ref name="preservar"/>
The [[National Pyrotechnic Festival|Feria Nacional de la Pirotecnia (National Pyrotechnics Festival)]] occurs each year in March in Tultepec, featuring a national competition of castillos.<ref name="arriesgan"/> Most attendance for the event is for the piromusicales competition, which draws about 10,000 spectators. There are also competitions for toritos and castillos.<ref name="reseña">{{cite web |url= http://www.soymexiquense.com/es/edomex/tultepec/125-resena-feria-nacional-de-la-pirotecnia-2012 |title= Reseña Feria nacional de la Pirotecnia 2012 |publisher=State of Mexico |location=Mexico |date=March 10, 2012 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Overview of the Feria nacional de la Pirotecnia 2012 |accessdate=June 8, 2012 }}</ref>
==Danger== [[File:Fatotonilco.jpg|thumb|Fireworks exploding over church in [[Atotonilco de Tula]] Mexico]] The industry is a dangerous one, mostly due to lack of enforcement of existing safety laws and regulation and lack of professional training.<ref name="preservar"/> A Tultepec mural shows townspeople, some lacking hands, lighting powder kegs and among castillos.<ref name="usatoday"/> In the State of Mexico alone, there are about 500 artisans who make fireworks illegally, without the proper training or facilities and without permission from authorities. According to the Instituto Mexiquense de la Pirotecnia, the main reason for this is that their manufacture is mostly done in families, rather than in factories.<ref name="existen500">{{cite news |title= Existen 500 artesanos de la pirotecnia irregulares en Edomex |url= http://www.oem.com.mx/laprensa/notas/n2490879.htm |newspaper= El Sol de Toluca |location=Toluca, Mexico |date=April 2, 2012 |accessdate=June 8, 2012 |language=Spanish |trans-title=There are 500 unlicensed pyrotechnic artisans in the State of Mexico }}</ref> Most accidents have happened in Tultepec, with 46 explosions in the municipality in 2002 alone, with a total of twelve dead and dozens hurt.<ref name="elgrito"/> In 2011, there were fourteen explosions in La Saucera, none of which were fatal, and one in a clandestine shop that left four people dead.<ref name="arriesgan"/>
There have been a number of notable accidents related to the manufacture and sale of fireworks in Mexico. In 1998, an explosion in a workshop in the Barrio de San Agustín neighborhood in Tultepec affected over one hundred houses and killed ten neighbors.<ref name="preservar"/> In 1999, [[Celaya fireworks disaster|an explosion]] in [[Celaya]] left 56 dead and 350 hurt.<ref name="elgrito"/> In 2003, there was an explosion at the Miguel Hidalgo Market in [[Veracruz, Veracruz|Veracruz]], which started at a clandestine fireworks warehouse that resulted in 28 dead, 35 hurt and 52 missing.<ref name="elgrito"/> In 2006, an explosion at the San Pablito market was attributed to a product called a “cerillo” (match), which consists of a colored stick with chemicals on both ends which produces sparks when scraped on a surface. This led to a yearlong ban on the product so its safety could be reevaluated.<ref name="preservar"/> The last major accident in Tultepec was in 2016 when a [[2016 San Pablito Market fireworks explosion|major fireworks explosion in San Pablito]] killed at least 32.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/articulo/metropoli/cdmx/2016/12/21/suman-32-muertes-por-explosion-en-tultepec|title=Suman 32 muertes por explosión en Tultepec|newspaper=El Universal|access-date=2016-12-21}}</ref>
==Sales==
In Mexico, fireworks, especially large rockets called “cohetones” are a staple of patron-saint festivals.<ref name="usatoday"/> Religious festivals even in the smallest towns have fireworks, which can include images of the patron saint on a frame outlined in pyrotechnics. This is particularly true to large pilgrimage sites such as that of [[Our Lady of San Juan de los Lagos]].<ref name="elgrito"/> The biggest day for fireworks sales is [[Mexico’s independence day]]. For [[Celebration of Mexican political anniversaries in 2010|Mexico’s Bicentennial celebration]] at the Zocalo or main square in Mexico City, over 2,400 shells composed the multimedia spectacular which begins by a reenactment of Father [[Miguel Hidalgo]]’s call for troops at 11 pm September 15, 1810.<ref name="recorre"/>
There are three markets specializing in fireworks, San Pablito in Tultepec, one in [[Chimalhuacán]] and the other in Zumpango, with San Pablito being the most important in the country.<ref name="arriesgan"/><ref name="concurso"/>
National sales of fireworks fluctuates between 800,000 and 1,700,000 [[Mexican peso|pesos]] per year.<ref name="exportaran">{{cite web |url= http://poderedomex.com/notas.asp?id=75595 |title= Juegos pirotécnicos hechos por manos mexiquenses se exportarán al país vecino del norte |publisher=State of Mexico |location=Mexico |date=April 25, 2012 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Pyrotechnic sets made by Mexican hands to be exported to neighboring country |accessdate=June 8, 2012 }}</ref> Only thirteen Mexican enterprises export abroad, mostly because they do not meet the standards for fireworks set by the United States, the closest major international market.<ref name="usatoday"/><ref name="exportaran"/> Mexican fireworks tend to be more powerful than mass-produced Chinese ones, which account for most of legal sales in the United States, which tempts many Americans to try and bring them across the border for [[Fourth of July]] celebrations.<ref name="usatoday"/>
Mexican fireworks are mostly promoted by the State of Mexico’s Instituto Mexiquense de Pirotecnia, which sponsors events such as art exhibits with a pyrotechnic theme and puppet shows on fireworks safety for children.<ref name="neza">{{cite news |title= Exponen pirotecnia en Neza |author= Héctor Ledezma |url= http://www.eluniversaledomex.mx/nezahualcoyo/nota4415.html |newspaper=El Universal |location=Toluca |date=June 29, 2010 |accessdate=June 8, 2012 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Exhibit pyrotechnics in Ciudad Nezahuacoyotl }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} {{Crafts of Mexico}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2017}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=January 2013}} {{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = Ministry for Culture and Heritage
Manatū Taonga |logo = MCH-logo.png |logo_width = |logo_caption = |seal = |seal_width = |seal_caption = |formed = 1 September 1999 |preceding1 = Ministry of Cultural Affairs |dissolved = |superseding = |jurisdiction = [[New Zealand]] |headquarters = [[Public Trust Building]]
131–135 Lambton Quay
[[Wellington]] 6011 |employees = |budget = Total budgets for 2017/18{{cite web| url=http://www.treasury.govt.nz/budget/2017/summarytables/estimates/09.htm| title=Total Appropriations for Each Vote| work=2017 Budget| publisher=The Treasury}}
''Vote Arts, Culture and Heritage''
{{increase}}$317,995,000
''Vote Sport and Recreation''
{{steady}}$89,195,000 |minister1_name = [[Jacinda Ardern|Rt Hon Jacinda Ardern]] |minister1_pfo =
Minister for Arts, Culture and Heritage {{cite web|title=Ministerial List|url=https://www.dpmc.govt.nz/our-business-units/cabinet-office/ministers-and-their-portfolios/ministerial-list|publisher=[[Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet (New Zealand)|Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet]]|accessdate=26 October 2017}} |minister2_name = |minister2_pfo = |chief1_name = Paul James
Chief Executive |chief1_position = |chief2_name = |chief2_position = |parent_agency = |child1_agency = |website = {{URL|http://www.mch.govt.nz}} |footnotes = }} The '''Ministry for Culture and Heritage''' ('''MCH''') ([[Māori language|Māori]]: ''Manatū Taonga'') is the public service department of New Zealand charged with advising the [[Government of New Zealand|government]] on policies and issues involving the [[Creative New Zealand|arts]], [[Culture of New Zealand|culture]], [[New Zealand Historic Places Trust|heritage]], [[Sport New Zealand|sport and recreation]], and [[Public broadcasting in New Zealand|broadcasting]] sectors, and participating in functions that advance or promote those sectors. ==History== The Ministry was founded in 1999 with the merger of the former Ministry of Cultural Affairs and the history and heritage functions of the [[Department of Internal Affairs (New Zealand)|Department of Internal Affairs]], as well as some functions from the [[Department of Conservation]] and [[Ministry of Commerce (New Zealand)|Ministry of Commerce]].{{cite web|url=http://www.mch.govt.nz/about-ministry/overview/history-government-involvement-culture|title=History of Government involvement in culture|website=Ministry for Culture and Heritage|accessdate=26 February 2017}}{{cite press release|author=Marie Hasler|date=28 July 1999|url=https://www.beehive.govt.nz/release/cultural-and-heritage-sector-some-relevant-questions-and-answers|title=Cultural and Heritage sector – some relevant questions and answers|accessdate=26 February 2017}} The purpose of the merger of functions and departments was to create a coherent, non-fragmented overview of the cultural and heritage sector, rather than spreading services and functions across several departments. Minister for Cultural Affairs [[Marie Hasler]] oversaw the transition of functions into the new agency. Opposition Labour MP [[Judith Tizard]], who would later serve as an Associate Minister for the ministry in the [[Fifth Labour Government of New Zealand]], accused the restructure of being "all hype, no substance," lacking the funding and human resource necessary to be effective.{{cite press release|author=Judith Tizard|url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/PA9907/S00546/all-hype-no-substance.htm|title=All hype, no substance|date=28 July 1999|accessdate=26 February 2017}} The Ministry of Cultural Affairs had been created in 1991; prior to this, the Department of Internal Affairs had provided oversight and support for arts and culture functions. At the time of its establishment, the responsible minister for the ministry was the Minister for Culture and Heritage. This position is now titled the [[Minister for Arts, Culture and Heritage]]. == Functions == The ministry advises the government on policies and issues relating to the arts, culture, heritage, sport and recreation, and broadcasting sectors. It funds 17 other agencies which also support these sectors,{{cite web|url=http://www.mch.govt.nz/funding-nz-culture/agencies-we-fund|title=Agencies we fund|website=Ministry for Culture and Heritage|accessdate=26 February 2017}} looks after monuments and war graves throughout New Zealand and is involved in a number of projects promoting and documenting New Zealand history.{{cite web|url=http://www.mch.govt.nz/what-we-do/our-projects|title=Our projects|website=Ministry for Culture and Heritage|accessdate=26 February 2017}} ===Agencies=== * [[Creative New Zealand]] (Arts Council of New Zealand) * [[New Zealand Music Commission]] * [[New Zealand Symphony Orchestra]] * [[Royal New Zealand Ballet]] * [[Te Matatini]] Society Inc. * [[Broadcasting Standards Authority]] * [[New Zealand Film Commission]] * [[NZ On Air]] * [[Radio New Zealand International]] * [[Antarctic Heritage Trust]] * [[Heritage New Zealand]] * [[Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa]] (Te Papa) * [[Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision]] * [[Pukaki Trust]] * [[Te Māori Manaaki Taonga Trust]] * [[Drug Free Sport New Zealand]] * [[Sport New Zealand]] (Sport NZ) ===Guardianship=== In 2014 the ministry became the guardian of the [[Television New Zealand Archive|TVNZ Archive]] collection on behalf of the crown.{{cite press release |author= |title=Budget 2014: Better access to NZ’s TV heritage|url=https://www.beehive.govt.nz/release/budget-2014-better-access-nz’s-tv-heritage|publisher=New Zealand Government|date=May 21, 2014|access-date=2017-12-16}} It appointed [[Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision]] as the initial archive manager. The TVNZ Archive collection contains over 600,000 hours of television spanning almost 55 years of New Zealand's public television history.{{cite speech|title=Draft speech|first=Craig|last=Foss|event=Function to mark the transfer of responsibility for the TVNZ Archives to the New Zealand Film Archive|location=Wellington, New Zealand|date=July 31, 2014|url=https://fyi.org.nz/request/6578/response/22258/attach/4/Joss%20J%20OIA%20documents%20for%20release.pdf|access-date=2017-12-16}} It includes iconic New Zealand content such as documentaries, dramas, sports programmes{{cite report|author=Ministry for Culture and Heritage|date=February 14, 2013|title=TVNZ Archive - Update on IP issues (briefing 2014/36)|url=https://fyi.org.nz/request/6578/response/22258/attach/4/Joss%20J%20OIA%20documents%20for%20release.pdf|page=11|access-date=2017-12-16}} and every TVNZ news broadcast from December 1986 to 2014.{{cite web|title=Video: Preserving the TVNZ Collection|url=https://ngataonga.org.nz/preservation/our-preservation-work/video-preserving-the-tvnz-collection|access-date=2017-12-28}}{{cite web|title=Official Information Act request (5402)|url=https://fyi.org.nz/request/5402-avalon-archive-facility-follow-up-information-requested|access-date=2018-04-20}} In a 2014 briefing to Minister [[Craig Foss]], the ministry noted that the long-term preservation of the TVNZ Archive collection did not align with the broadcaster's business needs and that transferring the collection to the crown would allow for the proper preservation of the collection.{{cite report|author=Ministry for Culture and Heritage|date=March 21, 2014|title=TVNZ Archive transfer - update (briefing 2014/107)|url=https://fyi.org.nz/request/6578/response/22258/attach/4/Joss%20J%20OIA%20documents%20for%20release.pdf|page=16|access-date=2017-12-16}} Both the ministry and TVNZ explicitly wanted to ensure the archive was preserved and that it was made increasingly available for re-use through online streaming and other means.{{cite web|url=https://fyi.org.nz/request/4927/response/17172/attach/4/MOU%20Access%20to%20TVNZ%20Archive%20Collection%20new%20scan.pdf|title=Memorandum of Understanding - Access to TVNZ Archive Collection, between the Ministry for Culture and Heritage and the Department of Internal Affairs|access-date=2017-12-16}} ===History and heritage=== The ministry supports research into and promotion of [[New Zealand history]]. This includes publication of New Zealand history books and e-books, and a number of websites. The ministry's managed sites include:{{cite web|url=http://www.mch.govt.nz/what-we-do/websites-we-run|title=Websites we run|website=Ministry for Culture and Heritage|accessdate=26 February 2017}} * '''New Zealand History Online''' * [[Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand]] * [[Dictionary of New Zealand Biography]] * '''[https://ngatapuwae.govt.nz/ Ngā Tapuwae trails]''' * '''WW100''' * '''Landmarks Whenua Tohunga''' David Green, a historian working for the ministry, discovered that significantly more New Zealand personnel were engaged in the [[Gallipoli Campaign]] than had been recorded in [[Fred Waite (politician)|Fred Waite]]'s official history, ''The New Zealanders at Gallipoli''. Waite's number of some 8,500 men was corrected to approximately 13,000 in September 2013.{{cite web |title=New research: How many New Zealanders served on Gallipoli? |url= http://www.gallipoli2015.govt.nz/new-research-how-many-new-zealanders-served-on-gallipoli |publisher=[[New Zealand Defence Force]] |date=3 September 2013|accessdate=10 December 2013}} Landmarks Whenua Tohunga is a partnership between the Ministry, the [[Department of Conservation Te Papa Atawhai]], [[Heritage New Zealand Pouhere Taonga]] and the Ministry of Business, Innovation and Employment. The programme promotes and encourages people to visit New Zealand’s historically and culturally important places. Landmarks has been launched so far in Northland and Otago. {{cite web|url=http://www.mch.govt.nz/landmarks-whenua-tohunga|title=Landmarks Whenua Tohunga|website=Ministry for Culture and Heritage|accessdate=15 January 2018}}. ===Legislation=== The ministry is also responsible for overseeing dozens of current acts and regulations.{{cite web |url= http://www.legislation.govt.nz/all/results.aspx?search=qs_all%40act%40bill%40regulation_%22Ministry+for+Culture+and+Heritage%22_resel&p=1 |title=Search – New Zealand Legislation |work=legislation.govt.nz |year=2011 |accessdate=30 October 2011}} These include: * Administering the following [[Order in Council|Orders in Council]]: ** [[Canterbury Earthquake (Historic Places Act) Order 2011]]{{cite web |url= http://www.legislation.govt.nz/regulation/public/2011/0231/latest/whole.html |title=Canterbury Earthquake (Historic Places Act) Order 2011 (SR 2011/231) – New Zealand Legislation |work=legislation.govt.nz |year=2011 |accessdate=30 October 2011}} ** [[Television New Zealand (Separation of Transmission Business) Order 2003]]{{cite web |url= http://www.legislation.govt.nz/regulation/public/2003/0323/latest/whole.html |title=Television New Zealand (Separation of Transmission Business) Order 2003 (SR 2003/323) (as at 21 November 2003) – New Zealand Legislation |work=legislation.govt.nz |year=2011 |accessdate=30 October 2011}} **[[Historic Places Trust Elections Regulations 1993]]{{cite web |url= http://www.legislation.govt.nz/regulation/public/1993/0302/latest/whole.html |title=Historic Places Trust Elections Regulations 1993 (SR 1993/302) (as at 31 January 2007) – New Zealand Legislation |work=legislation.govt.nz |year=2011 |accessdate=30 October 2011}} * Administering the following [[Act of Parliament|Acts of Parliament]]: ** [[Broadcasting Act 1989]]{{cite web |url= http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/1989/0025/latest/whole.html |title=Broadcasting Act 1989 No 25 (as at 01 July 2011), Public Act – New Zealand Legislation |work=legislation.govt.nz |year=2011 |accessdate=30 October 2011}} ** [[Television New Zealand Act 2003]]{{cite web |url= http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/2003/0001/latest/whole.html |title=Television New Zealand Act 2003 No 1 (as at 23 July 2011), Public Act – New Zealand Legislation |work=legislation.govt.nz |year=2011 |accessdate=30 October 2011}} ** [[Protected Objects Act 1975]]{{cite web |url= http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/1975/0041/latest/whole.html |title=Protected Objects Act 1975 No 41 (as at 01 April 2011), Public Act – New Zealand Legislation |work=legislation.govt.nz |year=2011 |accessdate=30 October 2011}} ** [[Historic Places Act 1993]]{{cite web |url= http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/1993/0038/latest/whole.html |title=Historic Places Act 1993 No 38 (as at 01 April 2011), Public Act – New Zealand Legislation |work=legislation.govt.nz |year=2011 |accessdate=30 October 2011}} ** [[National War Memorial Act 1992]]{{cite web |url= http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/1992/0020/latest/whole.html |title=National War Memorial Act 1992 No 20 (as at 01 October 2000), Public Act – New Zealand Legislation |work=legislation.govt.nz |year=2011 |accessdate=30 October 2011}} ** [[Radio New Zealand Act 1995]]{{cite web |url= http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/1995/0052/latest/whole.html |title=Radio New Zealand Act 1995 No 52 (as at 25 January 2005), Public Act – New Zealand Legislation |work=legislation.govt.nz |year=2011 |accessdate=30 October 2011}} ** [[Anzac Day Act 1966]]{{cite web |url= http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/1966/0044/latest/whole.html |title=Anzac Day Act 1966 No 44 (as at 01 April 2004), Public Act – New Zealand Legislation |first= |work=legislation.govt.nz |year=2011 |accessdate=30 October 2011}} ** [[New Zealand Film Commission Act 1978]]{{cite web |url= http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/1978/0061/latest/whole.html |title=New Zealand Film Commission Act 1978 No 61 (as at 25 January 2005), Public Act – New Zealand Legislation |work=legislation.govt.nz |year=2011 |accessdate=30 October 2011}} ** [[Flags, Emblems, and Names Protection Act 1981]]{{cite web |url= http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/1981/0047/latest/whole.html |title=Flags, Emblems, and Names Protection Act 1981 No 47 (as at 07 July 2010), Public Act – New Zealand Legislation |work=legislation.govt.nz |year=2011 |accessdate=30 October 2011}} ** [[Archives, Culture, and Heritage Reform Act 2000]]{{cite web |url= http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/2000/0032/latest/whole.html |title=Archives, Culture, and Heritage Reform Act 2000 No 32 (as at 01 November 2006), Public Act – New Zealand Legislation |work=legislation.govt.nz |year=2011 |accessdate=30 October 2011}} ** [[Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa Act 1992]]{{cite web |url= http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/1992/0019/latest/whole.html |title=Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa Act 1992 No 19 (as at 25 January 2005), Public Act – New Zealand Legislation |work=legislation.govt.nz |year=2011 |accessdate=30 October 2011}} ** [[Arts Council of New Zealand Toi Aotearoa Act 1994]]{{cite web |url= http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/1994/0019/latest/whole.html |title=Arts Council of New Zealand Toi Aotearoa Act 1994 No 19 (as at 01 January 2009), Public Act – New Zealand Legislation |work=legislation.govt.nz |year=2011 |accessdate=30 October 2011}} ** [[New Zealand Film Commission Act 1978]] * Consultation responsibilities under many acts relating the [[Treaty of Waitangi]] settlements. **[[Port Nicholson Block (Taranaki Whānui ki Te Upoko o Te Ika) Claims Settlement Act 2009]]{{cite web |url= http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/2009/0026/latest/whole.html |title=Port Nicholson Block (Taranaki Whānui ki Te Upoko o Te Ika) Claims Settlement Act 2009 No 26, Public Act – New Zealand Legislation|work=legislation.govt.nz |year=2011 |accessdate=30 October 2011}} **[[Ngaa Rauru Kiitahi Claims Settlement Act 2005]]{{cite web |url= http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/2005/0084/latest/whole.html |title=Ngaa Rauru Kiitahi Claims Settlement Act 2005 No 84 (as at 23 May 2008), Public Act – New Zealand Legislation |work=legislation.govt.nz |year=2011 |accessdate=30 October 2011}} == Ministers == The ministry serves two portfolios, two ministers and an associate minister.{{cite web|url=https://www.dpmc.govt.nz/cabinet/portfolios/arts-culture-and-heritage|title=Arts, Culture and Heritage|author=|date=|website=Arts, Culture and Heritage}} {| class="wikitable" |- ! Officeholder !! Portfolio(s) !! Other responsibilities |- | [[Jacinda Ardern|Rt Hon Jacinda Ardern]] || Lead Minister (Ministry for Culture and Heritage)
[[Minister for Arts, Culture and Heritage]] || |- | [[Grant Robertson|Hon Grant Robertson]] || Minister for Sport and Recreation || Associate Minister for Arts, Culture and Heritage |- | [[Carmel Sepuloni|Hon Carmel Sepuloni]] || || Associate Minister for Arts, Culture and Heritage |} ==See also== * ''[[Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand]]'' * [[Jock Phillips]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{Official|http://www.mch.govt.nz/}} *[http://www.nzhistory.net.nz/ New Zealand History Online] {{NZ Public Service Departments}} [[Category:New Zealand Public Service departments]] [[Category:Arts in New Zealand]] [[Category:Cultural heritage of New Zealand]]
